title: Sharing my BP1 survival binder
content:
This is my way to help manage my bipolar disorder, track my mood, and stay organized. It also keeps all my crisis resources in one place. The table of contents is color-coded, and I added tabs in corresponding colors to the binder to make it easy to find everything. At the back, I’m planning to use a planner insert for mood tracking along with a ‘year in pixels’ page, so I can see how my mood was over the year. I’m a really visual person, so having everything laid out like this feels super helpful.

I’m kind of hyper-fixating on it right now, but it feels good to have a productive distraction. If anyone has ideas or tips before I print it, I’d love to hear them!

title: Do you know anyone with bipolar in your life?
content: I don’t know anyone in my personal life that have bipolar and it makes me feel really isolated and misunderstood. I also haven’t seen or heard of many older people with bipolar disorder. I was just wondering if you know people with bipolar and about how old they are. It scares me that I don’t know older people with the disorder. I’m 31 years old and was diagnosed at 22 and I feel like I have struggled my whole life with stability. Does it get easier to get stable the older you are? Do the episodes get less intense? I have no one to ask. The only bipolar person I knew was my grandfather and he died when I was young and I didn’t know he was bipolar until my parents told me when I was diagnosed.

title: I’m… happy?
content:
I feel happy lately. Not mania happy. Like genuinely happy. We upped my meds and I finally feel normal. Not in a flat way, in a content, happy way. I just feel mentally calm. Even my anxiety has been loads better. Granted I quit a job that I hated, so I don’t have that weighing on me. But I really feel like it was the med change. 

Just wanted to share! 😬

title: Does anybody ever get the urge to tell everyone you're bipolar?
content:
I've been well medicated and stable and look completely normal(on the outside) so i doubt anybody thinks i have bipolar. The only people who know about my bipolar is my immediate family, my therapist and two close friends.

I wish everybody would acknowledge and understand the pain I have to go through to get through life everyday. But then I would have to live through judgement and prove my feelings are valid every time.

One thing that really annoys me is whenever I get anxious, upset, or sad for a reasonable reason anyone normal would act that way. I'm just being too bipolar or I need to take my meds.

Does anybody else struggle with this?

title: i just found out that a friend of mine from treatment passed away
content:
i spent ages 16-18 in 3 different inpatient treatment centers. the last program i was in was a yearlong residential, and consisted of around 40 others my age. the program put an emphasis on peer mentorship, and towards the end (when i'd stabilized) i was trusted with mentoring several new clients: being roommates with them, guiding them, getting them accustomed to life there, and being someone they could rely on and trust. 

today, i found out that one of the clients that i'd been a peer mentor to in the final few months of my stay there passed away. he was around a year younger than me. i'm 19. 

he struggled a lot and i always tried to help him. we had similar issues as well as interests, and i really saw his potential. he was so funny. things he said would be repeated and referenced by other clients for weeks after. he loved music, and i'd give him guitar lessons and let him listen to music on my mp3 player (you could only have one after a certain point in the program and he hadn't reached that yet while i was there). when i left, i gave him my mp3 player and wished him the best, and he told me he loved me.

after leaving, i tried to find his contact info a few times but couldn't. i asked others that i'd been in the treatment center with about him but most said that he'd gotten kicked out and they didn't know where he was after. i assumed that he'd eventually left treatment and moved on, not wanting contact with people from that period of his life. i had a phase like that. i didn't expect this. i'm shocked and feel awful. 

i'm sorry if this post doesn't exactly fit this subreddit, i don't really have anyone to talk to about this and don't know where else to put it. we were both in treatment for bp and substance use. it just really hurts.

title: I'm scared ya'll
content:
Diagnosed at the end of 2024 and the medication is working, but if I'm being truly honest I'm afraid to lose my personality. And I know that ultimately I am in fact finding my personality, but it doesn't change the fact that up until this point, the spark, the "genius" if you will, has been wrapped within mania. It feels good, it feels strong, I've done some of my best paintings you know? But it sucks because I'm 25 and I don't really feel like I know myself.

As the meds are kicking in, the ill part of my mind is going, "You can't think as fast, the meds are slowing you down, this is bad, the doctor was wrong." But in reality, for the first time in my life I can sit an enjoy something simple like sitting in the sun. I was showing symptoms by my teen years, I have had so little time to just exist unhampered by the abuse I faced as a child and my mental health issues. But losing that "edge" leaves me feeling scared and intensely vulnerable. However, I've been suicidal since I was 11 and I haven't been suicidal in 4 months, which is incredible for me.

It's also scary because my mother is also bipolar, but unmedicated, and as her daughter I was given a front row seat to her spectacularly bad decline. She went from a mostly functional but unlikable loner to a raging alcohol-homicidal maniac. I do not speak in hyperbole, she's threatened my father's life more than once and pulled a knife on me. I know the neuroprotective qualities of anti convulsants, but if I'm being real, a part of me fears getting into a relationship because of it. I have a hard enough time keeping friends. It's hard to realized how much this has effected my life up until this point. I believed I was stable, which is crazy. The "edge" I had felt good, but it and that cycle was wreaking HAVOC on my life. All of my family is already commenting on how much more functional I am, and it feels good. I guess, in sum, I'm meeting myself for the first time and I'm grateful for the opportunity, but I'm scared and feeling lonely.

title: Coworkers made me hypomanic.
content:
It was a short lived but very intense episode, a mixed state but doctor said it was still probably just hypomania.

My job right now is about to get real intense. I'm a department manager and as soon as I hear the news we're about to rebuild the store, I began feeling a sense of focus, happiness, and ya know, the general hyper emotions. Just not intense enough to raise red flags.

Shortly after, I made bet with one of my coworers we were gonna wake up at 4:30 every day. As soon as I began waking up at said time, taking my meds too early in the morning, I was on my way up really quickly. Still didn't notice signs.

I would talk much more without stuttering or breaking eye contact. I could do the most boring job and make it feel fantastic. I was super confident and productive at work too. I have a work crush, and I'd go up and talk to her so much more. We just talked, laughed and was vibing. I was charismatic as fuck.

The next couple of days I couldn't quite sleep or eat. But that didn't affect my energy levels much if anything at all. I got bad anxiety and was constantly jittery. Heart rate went up. Felt like I drank 25 cups of coffee in the morning. At this point I kinda realised something wasn't right.

I drove very recklessly without realising it. I'd drift, speed, miss traffic rules, blast music and sing along. I wen't on shopping sprees, reached out to old friends, wanted a tattoo, and stopped caring about my day to day routine. I'd have HORRIBLE anxiety when things didn't go my way. Friends didn't respond immediately? Got depressed. Forgot my headphones to the gym? Went back home to do something else. I did some bad online shopping, spent my savings for the month and could not sit still without having my heart race of anxiety.

Then I found out my crush had a boyfriend and got so depressed I was borderline s**cidal with even more anxiety + rage. I was still up, still amped the frick up, but with miserable thoughts.

I'm better now thanks to meds and stoicism.

title: I rly question how I will have a career
content: After being on the right meds I’m stable and you’d probably never be able to tell that I’m bipolar. Sometimes it’s hard for me to wrap my head around that. I’m in college now and in charge of my meds, I miss doses all the time I just keep forgetting bc It’s such a nuisance. but then I throw myself into an episode and remember all over again. Last semester just before finals week I felt depressed and stopped taking my meds which exasperated things and became basically bed bound for a week. Surviving off the snacks I keep stored under my bed. Then the day before my finals I woke up feeling great and refreshed and studied for like 7 hours straight. Not at all how I planned to study and obviously didn’t do as good as I had planned. Then when I’m hypomanic I get super detached and spiritual. You know I really want to go into medicine… I can’t imagine being a doctor while at the same time spewing that we are all god and believing that the universe is talking to me. What if I get bad again and need to be hospitalized for the bajillionth time?? At this point it is just annoying, because i know it’s just my bipolar. It’s not fair. How will I ever succeed in life?

title: “Mania”
content:
Artwork created during my last major manic episode… 

It was unfinished due to an extreme fall into depression, but I like it this way. I think it really shows my mental state at the time. 

Some background- I bleached and dyed my hair red during this time (never before had I ever touched my hair with bleach or color). It was something I decided on a whim one day after work. I did some quick research, went to Sally’s and did it that very night. It actually turned out quite well. I did go back to my natural color (as close as I could) whenever I got back to a somewhat stable baseline. I will always associate my red hair with this episode. I made some terrible decisions that caused significant stress in my personal life, but I was able to recognize I needed health. For the first time I went to my psychiatrist and told him my meds weren’t working correctly and I needed help. I was diagnosed with Bipolar and have steadily been healing and returning to a somewhat normal baseline. It’s crazy looking back at this time because it seems like a completely different person took over for that period of time. I do not know her, and I don’t want to ever meet her again.

title: Dating
content:
Hey my fellow bipolar peeps, I wanted to share my tips with dating and having bipolar.

You will save yourself a lot of pain and heartache by telling them early on (like first date). I explain to them what I was like before I was medicated and what I am like now that I am medicated. 

Pay attention to how they react once you tell them, if they get excited RUN, some people have weird kinks with people with mental illness believing they are the best in bed & will string u along for that purpose only. If they ask questions and appear open minded that’s usually a good sign that this person believes they could have a meaningful relationship with someone with bipolar. 

There is someone out there for everyone and not holding back your personality or emotions early on will make it clear whether they are meant for you or not. There is no sense in being with someone where your teetering on an edge wondering if your doing to much or not. It will only put more strain on your mental health. 

I hope you guys all find love, we deserve it just like the rest but most importantly remember to love yourself and put yourself first during your search <3

title: How did you become okay with being bored (or feeling boring)

I don’t feel like participating in my old hobbies anymore because they seem like a waste of time now (painting, reading mainly). I feel like I’ve become more boring as a person. I used to go on a new adventure everyday looking for something stimulating or fun (not even bad things just like going to a new arcade or new cafe). I used to have so much energy and while I don’t feel sedated, I guess I feel base line but after mania it feels very slow. Now I just go to school, eat dinner and watch YouTube videos. 

My head is quiet and that leaves for a lot of room to do things since I’m not constantly fighting back fires but like…what do I do now, man? Is this stability? It just feels unnerving and a bit meaningless.

title: Feel kinda alone and want to rant about struggle recently
content:
Just going to start off by saying I’m doing 100 percent better than I was last year at this time and I should give myself more credit than I am now. Just want to rant and see if anyone can relate. 

I had my first manic episode last year and was diagnosed with bipolar 1. I struggled with anxiety through last year but eventually I started trade school to be an industrial maintenance tech. I found a decent cocktail of meds and quit all substances except caffeine. 

The main problems I have been experiencing lately are bouts of boredom and loneliness. Half of my day is spent at school and I really like it because I feel productive and I am interested in the subjects and I love the atmosphere of the school. The problem arises when I come home and feel like no one is there to appreciate what I am doing and be interested in me and ask about my day. Video games just don’t hit as hard as they used to and most of my friends are busy and don’t care about what I did today or how I am doing on that specific day. I would love to hear how there day went but a lot of the time they don’t want to talk about it. 

I have started looking into getting a job after school to distract me from boredom and thinking about this kind of thing too much while also having a little bit of income but I just feel down everyday after school even though at school I love it and It feels exhilarating. Maybe it’s just emotional sensitivity but i feel lonely. I have been thinking about maybe getting some sort of girlfriend to talk to about my day to converse in a loving way back and forth but I don’t really know if that’s a good idea considering that it is a really emotional thing to commit to as well as I may be moving and or traveling for work in 6 months. Maybe I just need to find other things to do outside of school and get a small job to keep me occupied.

title: The death of mania
content:
Step 1: Stop taking meds 
Step 2: Get manic 
Step 3: Do manic shit
Step 4: Crash 
Step 5: Panic because I can’t handle the depression and go back on meds 

This is a normal cycle for me. Been doing it for years. There’s a lot of reasons for it that I’m still trying to sort through. And maybe I just have yet to make that one manic mistake to scare me to stay on meds. But getting back on meds this time and slowly being able to think more clearly I’ve made some realizations.

Realization #1:Meds do not make you happy. Meds make you stable and even. I think the biggest misconception I’ve been holding on to is that if I stay on meds I’ll be happy. But that’s not at all the case. There’s no such thing as a pill for happiness.

Realization #2: Meds don’t fix everything. Sure they may lower the volume but they are not a cure. There is not cure. Girl you have bipolar just accept it.

Realization #3: The euphoria you feel when manic is not what happiness feels like. There’s a difference between feeling euphoric while manic and feeling happy.

Realization #4: You can’t live in constant chaos. That’s not living, it’s surviving. I know you think the only time you truly feel alive is when you’re manic but you know that’s not sustainable and you only end up in trouble.

Realization #5: Even though they don’t make you happy, you do feel better while taking meds. Things are so much quieter and calmer. You can think clearly and make rational decisions. You can sleep and function like a productive member of society. 

I will still miss feeling so unbelievably happy though. Feeling like I am made of light. Feeling so carefree. Feeling music so deeply in my soul. Feeling like I am amazing and can do no wrong. I mourn that feeling. I just feel like I’ll never feel truly happy again.

title: I’m a horrible wife
content:
For some background, I’m on a anti depressant/anti anxiety and my doctor hasn’t refilled it so I haven’t had my meds in a few days. We also have 2 toddlers (3M and 1M) and I’m 17 weeks pregnant. 

So my (22F) husband (23M) was admitted into a mental hospital a few days ago due to suicidal thoughts.

At first I was worried and happy he was getting help and super supportive, and just trying to hold down the fort and keep positive. But he called me the second day and told me he didn’t want to come home, at first we agreed to 5 days to give the medicine time to work and for him to talk to someone and get a feel for how he feels/get his mind straight, but now he wants to stay for 10 days or longer. 

I got extremely upset and cut the call short. I felt so horrible for getting so mad and I just couldn’t understand why he would want to stay there. 
For some more background: I was in a mental hospital years ago and I had a traumatic experience, so I didn’t want him to stay long because I don’t trust mental hospitals. 
So I kept getting more upset, while all of this is happening my youngest is constantly screaming making it really hard on me (his molars are coming in) and my heart is breaking with my oldest asking where daddy is all the time. 

He called me today, and I broke down crying my eyes out. I was upset because every time he calls me he’s having a great time, doesn’t ask about the kids or me, cuts our calls short because he has nothing to say to me, and how he doesn’t want to to come home. 

I just cried and yelled about how we all miss him so much, and I’m happy he’s getting help of course but it’s hard for me to hear him say every conversation he doesn’t want to come home and he’s having a great time. 

I hung up and just cried for 20 minutes. I feel so horrible and I’m such a horrible wife.

title: Things Will Get Better
content:
Good morning fellow Bipolars,

I just felt moved to encourage you all today and remind you that things will get better. I was diagnosed with Bipolar a couple years ago and up until the past few weeks it felt like I had tried every medication and form of treatment. Nothing was working. I just felt numb and like I could never be happy again. I lost hope. I was miserable every day and in and out of the hospital. After 25 years of trauma I cut off my abusive parents. I was so depressed I just knew my wife would leave me. But she didn’t.

Fast forward to now and I’m the most stable and happy I’ve ever been in life. Our marriage is the best it has been in 5 years. I found a family that loves me for who I am. After failing and failing with medications I finally found one that worked and keeps me stable. I started to see positives in life. This paired with a daily schedule I stick to prioritizing self care and health has changed my life. 

All of this being said I still battle this illness every day as I’m sure you all do. It is hard to accept we’re not “normal.” It is hard dealing with symptoms it feels like no one else has to deal with. But hang in there, time is your friend. It doesn’t happen overnight but you will start to build a toolbox of things that help minimize symptoms for you. Give yourself grace and try to remind yourself of the positives in life. Each of us are unique and special in our own way and should be proud of it. 

Please don’t hesitate to ask me any questions, I’d love to help in any way I can. I have come to find we can’t do this alone. 

Have a blessed day and and best of luck on your journey.

title: Either/or, all or nothing, and obsessions
content:
Hello fellow BPs. I will try to make this short and sweet, and if not, I will include a TL;DR.

I was diagnosed with BP1 about 10 years ago. Since finding the right meds about 8 years ago, things have been Ok. Not perfect, but manageable.

A few (many) years ago I competed at a fairly high level in sports. I switched a bit back and forth, until I found my "calling" in weightlifting, which I got totally obsessed with for many years and did quite well.

But circumstances (and shift in interests i guess..) got me to quit, now 6 years ago. And since then I have not had a sport to obsess about, which is bumming me out quite a bit. It's like I have this mindset that if I can't do it at an obsessive level, then why bother at all...

I am taking the right meds and generally loving life. I've found a great girlfriend and just bought a house. I am doing well in many aspects of life. But I am so sick of my obsessive behaviour getting in the way of enjoying stuff/sports on a regular level. I don't see the point in just going for a run, if I'm not training for a marathon. I don't see the poin in lifting weights if I don't plan on competing at the highest level. I don't see the point in training boxing, If I dont plan on knocking people out. And so on...

Can anyone relate? How do you deal with this?

TL;DR

My obsessive nature stops me from enjoying recreational activities. It's either/or, all or nothing.

title: Suicide rate
content:
The suicide rate for bipolar disorder from what I read online is 15-20% of us, with 30-60% having attempted. I nearly lost my life last year before I was sent to a mental hospital.

I feel a lot of sympathy for everybody here. Life is admittedly not easy for us, but the support given to me by everyone here means the world.

title: Talking to mental health professionals
content: I was diagnosed when I was 17, my mental health was so bad at that point my therapist was trying to get me to do ‘night school’ to finish early because being in a school environment was horrible for me. I stuck it out and finished the normal way as I was a senior and wanted to finish the way everyone else did. Something I’ve noticed is when I encounter a new (to me) mental health professional who tries to explain to me how bipolar works. Like pal, trust me, from first hand experience I KNOW HOW IT WORKS. I’ve had it my entire life. I’ve had multiple times when I’m with a professional who is new to me, ask what medicine I take and how it is doing for me, when were my last episodes and how long they lasted. I have had TWO professionals say my medicine isn’t what I should be taking since it’s an antidepressant, not a mood stabilizer. And I have to defend myself pretty much and explain that it helps me function and I feel fine with what it does for me. Why would I want to change from the medicine that I’ve been on for 8 years? Just because it’s not a mood stabilizer? It does what I need it to do. I even had one of them tell me “it shouldn’t be helping you like that” well guess what, it does. Don’t blame me. I had one recently try telling me that if I’m on medicine then I shouldn’t be having episodes. (My episodes aren’t as often or as bad now, they were awful before medicine). When I tell you my jaw almost dropped. Medicine doesn’t get rid of bipolar disorder. It helps make it easier to manage. That’s like telling someone with gout they shouldn’t be experiencing symptoms because they are on medication. You’re still gonna have flare ups! Just wanted to share.

title: How do you experience psychosis with depression?
content:
I've had a lot of episodes of depression, but only on three occasions have I had very clear psychosis with it. 

I get convinced that my brain is rotting and is full of maggots. I can feel them wriggling in my head, and I can smell this constant smell of rotting meat which perpetuates the delusion. I start thinking of ways that I can break open my skull to get the maggots out. 

One time it happened when I was still functioning enough to organise myself to do it, I went to my doctor and declared that she needed to perform trepanning on me, or else I was going to do it on myself. I fully intended to with an electric drill as well. That got me a hospital stay. 

The weird thing is that when I'm like this I don't feel suicidal at all. In fact, I'm actually scared that I'm dying. 

If you get psychosis with your depression, how do you experience it?

title: Dear fellow bipolars
content:
Hey. Thank you for persisting today. It's been hard. I promise, I can relate to your struggles. I was unstable and suicidal too, until last year, I started building stability and peace bit by bit. Nothing much changed on surface, but my life feels a lot different now.
Depressed brain is a survival mechamism. It helps you conserve your energy in unprofitable (or dangerous) situation. But it comes with cognitive impairment. 
When you're depressed, you feel as if your thoughts are unchangeable truth, which makes it difficult to climb out of the pit alone. 
 Right now, I believe that the best thing you can do for yourself is find hope and reasons to persist, even if it feels like there is none.
 When I started climbing out of that state,  I made a vision board and an antivision board to visualize and remind myself what I really wanted in life and didnt want, and why I should strive at all to survive.
 I listened to tons of music of all sorts, and podcasts and religious chants as a therapy. Listening to stories of people who have lived through trauma helped a lot too.
 Therapy helps yes. but I think what helps more is surrounding yourself with good people to check in with you daily - people who carry good energy to lift you up when you're down. And that takes luck, time, effort, and a ton of courage to open up your wounds to others and to ask for help. 
This is not easy, but help will come to you. only if you ask for help. Being vulnerable and acknowledging your struggles is not a weakness. it shows strength.
 Try to find what helps you feel better, and try to keep doing that, or even better, set up a system so it happens as a natural part of your routine.
 In my case, it was drinking tea and meditating, basketball, walking at parks, finding songs that help me release pent up feelings, writing out all my random thoughts on sticky notes and then either put them on walls, or crumple and put them in a locked container (i rarely reopen it but it helps me see how dark my thoughts were later)
Just, whatever you do, watch out not to isolate yourself for too long and spiral into your own negative thoughts.
 Let me know if you need a listening ear. I know you've got the grit and power in you. You've survived until today, and I'm so proud of you. Hope you find your stable life again.

Love,
Anonymous

title: Why is it so hard to cope with the dullness of medication??
content:
I recently got a new job after spending half of last year trying to find a new one. It is a job that  was in a completely new environment for me, with a lot to learn quickly. Big changes are a trigger for me to have episodes and I hadn’t been able to get my meds the whole time I was unemployed, so I was a little concerned and vigilant about my mental health during this transitional period. 

I had to wait till Jan 1st for my benefits to kick in and be able to see my psychiatrist again for the first time in forever. I said okay I just gotta make it 1 month holding it together, that’s easy! Then I had some crazy drama with my ex boyfriend which really was just the tipping point for me I guess lol I was already kind of building up to a hypo/manic episode but yeah I was there after that. I tried to schedule an appointment sooner and I got my meds refilled. It’s crazy because I really did try to keep an eye out for any signs and still, I was completely blindsided by it. Someone had to point out my behavior to me and I was like ohhhhhhhhhhhhhh shit lol you’re right……

The nausea I felt trying to get back on my medication made me just quit outright the first time. Then eventually I contacted the psychiatrist office again asking for guidance on how to deal with that side effect, he told me how to taper back onto them so I started that and the nausea went away completely. 

After a few days I could already feel a day and night difference and I was just so stunned at where I was at mentally for a few weeks up until this point and how did I not notice more??? But this always happens to me w/ antipsychotics, I feel so DULL coming off of a manic episode that they had to end for me. I actually cannot stand it and now I’m struggling to get myself to take them again. I liked feeling good. I don’t want to have to just sit with myself and get through my day with no excitement and interest to everything. I have an appointment at the end of the month and I feel like I’m gonna get yelled at lol. What’s the point of even talking to him if I’m not doing what I’m supposed to be doing. The closest person in my life who keeps an eye on me has already questioned me again about seeming a little hypo so I guess the roller coaster continues yet still. 

Anyways do y’all ever experience something similar where you feel the color sucked out of everything when you have to take meds for mania? Advice for how to suck it up?

title: In progress of getting a diagnosis and I’m a bit scared
content:
Hi everyone, I’ve been referred to a mental health team to be considered for a bipolar diagnosis. I’m in the UK and mental health services are so stretched here so this may take up to a month… I’ve had lots of time to over think about it!

I’ve been lurking on this subreddit for a couple of weeks and seeing the community and support is really lovely. I think that (if I am bipolar) my story is pretty similar to many here. I’m 28, have been diagnosed as depressed for nearly a decade, SSRIs made me feel very odd, doctors never saw my version of mania as it didn’t end in intervention so never considered bipolar. 

I sometimes stay up late into the night making art, I one day decided I could go and run a marathon with no training, I can go from being very withdrawn to very chatty and social, I’m very enthusiastic about an idea for a short time and then lose all interest, I’ve been a bit risky with dating and sex, I’ll feel totally unstoppable. A lot of these would be all in the same period.

I will then go to being deeply down and depressed, uncontrollably crying, I experience bad migraines in these periods too.

It’s been a relentless cycle for most of my adult life.

Having this potential diagnosis feels like it could finally be an answer for me but I’m also quite scared. I don’t really know how to approach a potential diagnosis- I expect it will happen as my behaviour is pretty well described by bipolar. Is there anything that people found helpful after a diagnosis/ how have you found coming to terms with a change in diagnosis. Also anyone who experiences bipolar and migraine? The comorbidity rates are really high. 

Thanks for reading!!

title: Thinking of dropping out in my last semester (tw sh/si)
content:
I’m in my last semester of a two year program. I’ve been greatly depressed for months. My first year at this school, my father died, I was SA’d by a close friend, and had an accidental overdose that the doctors said was all in my head. This year started and i was placed in a group with my assailant. Soon after i discovered a mass on my skull that doctors have no answer for. I got fired from my job because i was sick.

Last December was one of the darkest times I’ve had in years. I was attempting nearly twice a week, SH relapsed, started taking more pills and drinking and smoking still. All on and off campus. I was existing only in between my panic attacks. Winter break came and though i was still depressed, i calmed down a lot. 

I returned to my city last week and my symptoms started to ramp up again. Panic attacks, doom spirals. The semester starts today. I’m calm and really sedated right now, but I don’t want to go back. I have grown to be an unrecognizable person to myself. title: The Middle Ground
content:
Somewhere between the extremes,
I exist, suspended—
Not in chaos, not in calm,
but in the endless, restless in-between.

I wake up to a fog that doesn’t belong to the sun or the storm.
It’s not screaming, not silence—
just the hum of thoughts too loud to ignore
and too quiet to explain.

I drink my coffee and wonder if this is the day
I’ll do all the things I promised myself
or if I’ll sit, still as stone,
watching hours melt into shadows on my walls.

I think about the calls I haven’t returned,
the texts I’ve read a dozen times,
the "how are you?"s I can’t answer because I’m not sure myself.
I’ve been “fine” so often it’s practically my name now.

This isn’t the worst of it,
but it’s not good, either.
It’s not screaming into pillows
or feeling like my chest is full of broken glass,
but it’s not peace.
It’s just this:
a thousand unfinished things,
a million unsaid words.

I want to be better,
but some days, I don’t even know what “better” is.
Is it finishing the laundry?
Calling my mom back?
Or is it just making it to the next minute
without collapsing under the weight of my own mind?

People ask, "What’s wrong?"
How do I explain that it’s everything and nothing?
That I’m not drowning,
but the water’s up to my chin,
and I’m so tired of treading it alone?

Somewhere between the manic highs
and the rock-bottom lows,
there’s this middle ground
that doesn’t feel like a ground at all.
It feels like quicksand,
slowly pulling me down
while I smile and pretend it’s a beach day.

This isn’t the worst of it,
but it’s not easy, either.
And if you’re here, in this middle, too,
just know—I see you.
We’ll keep treading, keep floating.
It’s not everything,
but it’s something.

title: BD and empathy
content:
I've seen a few questions on bipolar disorder and empathy flying around Reddit. So I did some digging, because I also feel like my ability to empathise is affected in some way.

However, results seem so inconclusive. Some studies in the 2010s showed some effects on empathy in people with BD, including decreased cognitive empathy (i.e. we find it harder to read and understand people's mental state), and increased affective empathy (i.e. we feel or share other people's mental state to a greater extent). Some more recent studies have found that there actually aren't any effects on empathy in people with BD. Various neurological studies have shown that there are changes in the brain regions that are thought to affect empathy, but it is unclear if these changes actually produce an effect.

Personally, I do resonate with the decreased cognitive empathy and increased affective empathy. I often find it difficult to read people's faces for what their emotions are, especially when manic. But if it's obvious or they say something, especially when it's a negative emotion, I almost find myself disproportionately affected by it.

So, I'm obviously not doing a study here, but do these facts resonate with you? Or not? I also don't doubt that my feelings about how I emphasize are more rooted in my upbringing and socialization. But is this a shared sentiment?

title: Dear diary
content:
Okay. I am bipolar. Today I feel worse than I've felt in a long time. My meds have no effect on me today. I know what I did. I know I kept pushing myself. 

First, I asked questions of someone who I knew wouldn't give me answers. Then, the therapy. It was a lot today. I was ready. I swear I was! But it got to me. And then I shared. I shared a revelation, and I expected a reaction. It turned into me comforting someone else. 

I've broken today. All the hard work has gone. Rebuild. Again. I can't rebuild on this faulty foundation. And I can't seem to make myself remove the fault. I was given the chance. It would've worked. I could've gone into therapy with a broken heart, but a lighter soul. 

There's the part of me that says that I am the fault. And in some ways that's true. But I've invited someone into my life who is not given to falling for my masks. Someone who has so many masks themselves that they cannot remember their own face. And this person destroys me. The destruction began before I knew that it wasn't coming from me, and no matter how hard I try I cannot stop the wrecking ball in their control.

My delusions are making it harder. Is it possible I'm feeling the destruction in their mind, and I'm taking it for myself? Are these feelings actually mine, they are so different from who I've always been? Are they begging me to stay close, or is that what I want from them? I'm here to help, the universe sent me to heal this person, who am I to fight that? They gave me a piece of their soul for safekeeping, today I had a fight with this piece of soul and ordered it to go back, it was ready to be whole again, and I needed peace from someone else's feelings.

So now I'm alone in my body, but the peace I was expecting has not come. I'm still alone. I still haven't accepted that the future I can see so clearly in my head was just a fantasy to begin with. 

And I want a drink. I want to drown it all out like I used to. I want the deadened feeling that comes with drinking too much for too long. I want the freedom of having given up on life, and realizing that the only person who could've ever saved me was me, and I wasn't going to waste my time trying anymore. That was the life I left, for the promise of happiness and security. I squandered that life, my undiagnosed bipolar fighting and winning against the calm I had finally accomplished.

I should've rested more. I should've taken a break. I shouldn't have asked questions that I knew were going to cause this reaction. But I'm always fine until I'm not. I always have a handle on it until I don't. I'm always manic until I'm depressed. And my depression is no longer pure. I can't simply give up, put on my dead eyes and exist until I don't anymore. Now my depression comes with questions, insane delusions, and anxiety. My meds can't touch what my brain insists on experiencing. 

What if, when I wake up, I learn I'm going to keep feeling this? What is the point of continuing to grow and learn, when the result is everything hurts so much more? I know my wants and needs and patterns, but now I know the void must be filled by me. There is nothing left of me. Most is given to my disorder, the rest I hand out freely, hoping it's enough to fill someone else's void. 

My curse is this: I feel everything when I want to feel nothing. I feel nothing when I want to feel everything. And in between, I cannot think.

title: How to deal with a narcissistic parent?
content:
Really won the lottery with my parents.

 My (18f) Dad (60m) has bipolar, our relationship used to be pretty bad until his diagnosis, and got better after my parents divorce and finding the right medication cocktail. Despite his stability, my dad is still quite immature, but he is happy, stable and lives in a city that i am moving to in a few days. 

However, my mother (54f) is a different story. She has never seeked help, and has always been extremely abusive to both my brother (24m), even more so to me. I have been living with her for the past few weeks, and have remembered just how truely awful she can be and how frequently I am triggered by her behaviour. I am on the right meds, i attend therapy as often as I can afford, I am a good kid. I know that I am a good daughter. I’m tricky sometimes but i am doing my best, I promise. And it seems as though she’s hated me every chance she gets. Every time i offer an olive branch, a chance at a normal conversation, she says something needlessly cruel. I have a feeling she consistently complains about me to everyone around her, i feel as though my coworkers, my family, random adults i bump into on the street, they all know me and despise me. My mother has never taken accountability for her actions, and if she has, she was ‘manipulated’ into it, its never her fault. She has shifted situations into me being the primary manipulator and liar, i could recount so many times she has said something awful only to be called a gaslighter. 

My mother is extremely uneducated when it comes to bipolar, although she states to know more about it and has suffered more from it than me or my father. I feel as though she uses my diagnosis to gain sympathy and try to get reactions out of me to demonise me. 

I’m moving in a few days. I’m an adult. How do I navigate this relationship? I’m constantly triggered by even the idea of her or what she might say. I want her to seek help. I want her to be a mother. I don’t understand why she hates me so much. 

How do i stop being triggered as much by her? Even when i’m away from her for extended periods of time she finds ways to trigger both depressive and manic episodes.

title: ADHD and Bipolar, how do you manage both?
content:
Trigger warning: talk of psychosis, manic symptoms, and inpatient



I was diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder about a year ago after my second episode of manic psychosis. (I'm in my early 20's)
I've been able to get things under control and balanced out for the most part by taking mood stabilizers, but I was recently diagnosed with ADHD. 

I've seen so much improvement and felt so much relief upon adding a daily stimulent to my medication routine. (For context, I take an SSRI for depression because the majority of the time I suffer from major depression without treatment for it. I've only had 2 manic episodes and both lead to severe psychosis)

The last couple of weeks I've noticed some slight manic symptoms coming on: slight decrease in need for sleep, forgetting to eat/not becoming hungry, and slight detachment from reality.

A week ago I had my mood stabilizer increased in hopes that this would smooth things back out, but the last couple days I've been struggling with racing thoughts, forgetfulness, feeling overwhelmed, and feeling more distant from reality. 

This has been concerning for me because these are feelings I remember having before episodes occurred, but the last time I thought an episode may be starting, it was a false alarm and I had put myself into voluntary inpatient.

I'm going to call my provider in the morning, but I work night shift and it may be a couple days before she gets back to me.
I'm hoping another increase in my mood stabilizer will get things back on track, but does anyone have any thoughts on what I should do between now and then or even long term? 

I really appreciate it

title: I miss being smart.
content:
I’m not hating on myself or being dramatic and saying I’m absolutely “stupid” or anything, but I am definitely not as smart as I used to be. Nowhere near as sharp, either. I was a straight A student and now I’m 26 years old, on my 7th year of college, and barely getting by in class. I can’t think of things to talk about, I can’t remember shit, I can’t focus, and I’m just not as bright as I used to be. Sometimes I can’t figure simple things out and it’s so bothersome. Critical thinking has just gone out the window at this point. My brain literally feels like it is becoming smoother and smoother by the day. 

I haven’t read too much on the effects on the brain due to bipolar disorder and medication, but boy am I feeling em’. I just feel dumb. That’s it, that’s all. Thanks for letting me share.

title: I hate people
content:
I had a really long manic episode that my psychiatrist caught and tried so hard to bring me back down and it took two separate hospitalizations to bring me down completely.

I'm still in shock by the episode. A lot of people around me seemed to take advantage of the episode. People knew I was sick. I had a complete personality change. For context, I'm normally basically an asexual person. During the episode, I believed I was bisexual and opened my relationship. I'm so horrified by everything and I don't trust anyone. I can't believe people saw the change as "fun" and went along with it. My spouse even took advantage of it. 

I have a lot of mental damage from it and I hate people. There was even a "friend" who basically groomed me into having sex with them. I just laid there frozen during it. This all feels so ridiculous because it's all my fault for letting all this happened. I'm so disgusted with myself. I let so much bad happened to me. I also have seen some dark sides of people during it. A lot of the people knew about my bipolar disorder and knew I was having a manic episode. The "friend" made a joke saying he must be manic too during it.

I feel like shit for letting all these things happen. I would never in my right mind let these things happened. This "friend" was and still is in a relationship when it happened. My relationship is ruined because it allowed my spouse to go behind my back and "cheat" on me. While he let his "friend" did what he did. His SO doesn't know and I'm not allowed to say anything to avoid "drama" in the friend group.

I'm staying to myself from now on. I'll never trust again. I'm terrified of another manic episode. I'll never forgive myself. Now I'm diagnosed with severe bipolar 1 disorder.


Edit: For even more context about how bizarre this episode was: I have only been with my spouse sexually since I was 17 (one and only) and no one else until the last manic episode.

Edit2: I'm 29 now.

title: I'm So Tired Of Being Crazy
content:

title: i can’t deal with it
content:
‎‏I have been diagnosed with bpd and bipolar 1 with rapid cycling. 
‎‏I can never find peace; I go from one episode to another. It’s madness. I don’t know how to live with this or how to deal with everything happening to me. I can’t get used to the episodes. I also feel like I’ve made things worse by using nicotine. I haven’t told my family or my doctor about it because I don’t want my doctor to tell my family. I can’t even imagine what they would do if they found out.
‎‏I can’t accept being bipolar; it always makes things worse and worse. I’m constantly seeking help from anyone, anywhere. How can I stop being terrified of the hallucinations? How can I remind myself that they aren’t real? I’m so tired. I’ve tried so much, but no one not even my doctor or therapist has been able to help me. I’m on medication, but I still go through all of this. I hate that there’s no in-between for me. It’s been so long since I felt stable that I don’t even remember what it feels like. Mania and depression are both horrible, each in its own way, but mania especially forces me to deal with so much: losing money, driving recklessly, ruining relationships, self harm, and suicidal actions—but not because I want to die. I don’t even know why!

‎‏I end up in the emergency room. I deal with delusions, hallucinations, and so much more. I feel like I’m losing my mind. I lose touch with reality. My last episode was about a week ago, and I can’t recover because of what I saw. I’m at home, but why was I in a tunnel? I literally saw a real tunnel. It was terrifying. Everything around me was moving and trying to collapse on me. I saw my mother, but she looked different and terrifying. I wish I could express or draw what I see so others could understand and maybe help me or at least try to
‎‏How can I learn more about my symptoms and how to deal with them? How can I be a better person? I hate that I’ll have to live like this forever and take medication for the rest of my life. I wish I had never been born. I hate that I’ll have to keep dealing with these episodes again and again. I hate being like this. I hate this damn disorder.
‎‏There’s so much I want to vent about, but I don’t know how to find the right words. My posts have been deleted many times because of certain words I used. I don’t know how to express myself freely or describe what I’m going through without worrying about using words that might get my post removed. I hope this one doesn’t get removed either.

I no longer know what’s real and what’s not. Can you imagine reaching the age of almost 24 and not knowing who I am? I feel strange even when I look at myself 
I find nothing there .

title: Memory Problems
content:
Idk about the rest of you but I feel like my memory has deteriorated exponentially over these last few years. I’m 22 years old and feel senile with the way my memory is so spotty. I used to have a pretty spot on memory, I used to be able to describe whole diagrams I learned in class, recite whole story lines of novels instead of just a single chapter my brain sticks to.

Now my days have just gotten so blurry. Remembering conversations I had only hours ago is difficult. I honestly can’t remember most of my day by the next and it gets a little frustrating. 

All of this to ask, how do yall manage memory problems or retention difficulties?

I’ve found writing down physical task lists that I keep in a visible area has been helping me keep track of my day. I’ve been using a mood tracker to be able to reference for therapy since I can’t remember how or why I was feeling something days later. I’ve been using a physical planner to organize and memorize my schedule for the week too. Doing cross-word puzzles to keep my brain pumping. I’ve been trying a lot of stuff but was wondering what you guys also do?

title: Brain zaps but not withdrawing
content:
I first got brain zaps when I was actually tapering off one of my antidepressants to switch to another. They never fully went away although I would get them a lot less often. Now I’ve been on my combo for several months. 

Recently however (the past 2-3 weeks) I’ve been getting really bad brain zaps every night when I try to go to bed. I get brain fog in the evenings, but it seems as soon as I close my eyes I start to get the zaps. Sometimes it’s even paired with sleep paralysis and a racing heart. 

My psychiatrist thinks it’s my b12 levels and I’ve been taking supplements for the past several weeks. There’s been no relief. Also my blood tests are showing adequate b12 levels. I stopped smoking weed after being a chronic user for years, and I wonder if that has something to do with it. I hate how brain zaps are so understudied and there’s really no answers to why this is happening. Hoping someone has any advice or can relate to this.

title: A difficult discussion  around getting hypersexual symptoms
content:
I've been having flashbacks of things I've done during episodes. It makes me feel like I can't live normally. I have so much guilt and shame, I feel like a monster. 

The older I get, the less I remember the details. For example, how old I was, why I did what I did, how much time had passed since. 

I could use some guidance, if anybody has any advice on coping. Maybe advice on not letting memories control your life? 

One of the things I'm seeking advice on is letting go of guilt and shame surrounding getting hypersexual. For context, I've never slept with anyone. It's been years but there was occasions that I am not proud of. 

It's hard for me to admit to these things and share them, I'm in a fragile state, so I hope you all judge me it won't be too harshly. 

In the past, I've taken and sent risky photos to strangers when having an episode. It's out of character considering the face that I'm incredibly insecure about my body.  I've also went on a chat "roulette" type of site and did sexual acts. Looking back, I feel like a perverted monster. I'm sure not everybody wanted to see that and it's making me sick. 

I can't understand these behaviors or why they have happened but I also can't change them. As I've said, I don't recall the smaller details. It's all a blur. I know mental state is no excuse, but it hasn't happened since. 

For further context, I am in Therpay and have been for months now. I want to share these things with her but I'm too afraid. That I am a monster and that everybody here and in my life would think I'm a monster and vile.

It makes me want to SH a lot of the time. These memories along with other ones. Stupid choices.

Ps: I still get points where I'm hypersexual but I handle it within myself.  

I understand if you all hate me, please know I truly regret what I've done. These moments in my life make it impossible to live normally.

title: I’m so freaking mad
content:
I’ve been trying to find an actual bipolar specialist, and every goddamn hospital either doesn’t call back or they reject me.

I tried getting with my family’s general practitioner and they said I can schedule an appointment in December.

I haven’t had care in over a year, and no doctor will see me.

I’m currently on leftover mood stabilizer from 5 and a half years ago, and I’ve been breaking the pills so they last longer.

I’m taking enough to not have psychosis but not enough that I’m functioning properly.

I feel like I’m losing my goddamn mind, and I don’t know what to do. I’m tired of the freaking racing thoughts and the constant mood swings all day. I can barely settle down, and I feel crazy.

I can’t just go to any doctor though, because all the ones before screwed me over and made my mental health a million times worse because they don’t know how to treat bipolar.

I saw a doctor a couple months ago, and it was a freaking scam. It said he specialized in bipolar, but when I asked him he said that wasn’t true. Then he proceeded to not let me explain my issues, talk down to me, and try to sell me vitamin pills and red lights off Amazon. Then he completely rejects my request for a mood stabilizer that I knew worked for me, and gave me like the one with the most issues.

I hate the health system, and I hate having this disorder more. I especially hate having no money or job. 

I can’t do this anymore.

Sorry for ranting, I’m just so goddamn angry.

title: Beating the Dopamine-hunt
content:
Bipolar 2 -- I don't even know if it's connected, but why not assume such?

Basically, I get addicted to EVERYTHING. I'm in my early twenties but have already had some nasty scrapes with problematic sex, drinking, eating, nicotine consumption, gambling, marijuana use, even some harder drugs though those didn't stick, thank God. I feel no particular connection to hypomania or depression or neutrality.

  
Like, jeez, it cannot be normal to get addicted to literally everything, right? What do you guys do to fight off the constant cravings? I have wholesome hobbies, and try to keep busy with studies, work, exercise, and socializing, but an itch for one or several addictions is always there and every few weeks or months there's another capital-i Incident. Thankfully nothing life-ruining yet, but we've come close.

  
I'm thinking group therapy could be nice? I was in a PHP-IOP once and it was very good for me. A semi-anonymous accountability network, as I struggle opening up to family/friends/partner. Hmm. Thanks all!

title: I feel like I'm losing my mind
content:
I think this is my first time posting to reddit and oh boy what a weird way to start. I [M20] recently went to see a psychiatrist for the first time due to feeling depressed and anxious for like 2-3 months for seemingly no reason. They put me on an anti-depressant and almost immediately things started to feel better. I felt euphoric and finally deep-cleaned my room overnight. I didn't sleep for three days and didn't see a problem with it. Eventually, my doctor called to check in and I told them how I felt... they then informed me that I was probably in a hypomanic episode. 

They prescribed me some stuff to make me sleep and told me to stop taking the anti-depressant immediately. But while I waited for the prescription, things got worse. The other day I convinced myself that I was somehow superhuman and everyone around me was jealous. I also had a "delightful" conversation with my car radio, which I thought was somehow channeling the messages of dead people. I called my doctor and they scheduled me an appointment this week to talk about the possibility I'm bipolar.

My new medication has since brought me down from that level, but I still feel like I'm running on a motor and can't stop. I just yelled at my boyfriend for canceling our plans today and then proceeded to call him back immediately crying and begging him not to leave me (which he says he never intended to do). I feel like everyone is suddenly staring at me like I'm crazy. I also overheard my roommate saying she is starting to sleep with her door locked in case I suddenly "lose it". 
I just feel so alone right now. 

Prior to all of this happening, I was the guy that everyone went to for their troubles or when they were in crisis. But now that I'm the one struggling, everyone is suddenly too busy. Or worse, they're scared of me. I just can't shake this feeling that I'm somehow making all of this up to be self-destructive or something like that. I feel like I'm losing my mind.

title: When you realize you was bipolar?
content:
Context, I was 26 when diagnosed, but had issues around 21-22. 


College was when realized something was amiss, I became more aggressive, irritable and had more sexual desires than my partner could fill. 

Also certain meds like SSRIs mainly did more harm than good at the time, and going to a psych was used as a punishment for my teenage years and never got proper help for a good while. 

I'm medicated now and still have am occasional flare up, but nothing like in my early-mid 20s. Costed me jobs, almost caught me felonies, almost made irrational and negative life changing decisions. 


I should have gotten treatment as a teen as the signs were kinda there, but I didnt have full blown symptoms until my second year of college. Looking back, I should have gotten help 10 years ago.

title: Lack of sex drive

title: In losing everything and feel lost
content:
I got unexpectedly pregnant after a manic episode, and I’ve always wanted to be a mom but I feel like I’m not ready mentally and I’m so scared. I’m having her, and I love her, but I’m so fucking scared. 

I also have a huge fear of medical stuff especially needles and there is so much pain and needles involved. I need a 3 hour glucose test this Wednesday which is 4 blood draws in 3 hours and they don’t even have a room away from others so when I pass out I’m going to just be in the lobby infront of everyone and I’m so scared for that too 

I had to put down my childhood dog, I miss him so much and that already felt world changing alone never mind all this other stuff 

And now my parents are getting a divorce and my mom was kicked out of the house and I was super close to her so I don’t even have her to lean on 

My boyfriend is so supportive and helpful and I love him so much he’s supporting me so much through this but I feel so bad being an emotional wreck all the time 

Ontop of that I’m so anxious how my meds for bipolar are going to effect my baby but I can’t be taken off of them because I can’t be depressed or manic while pregnant with all the hormones making it worse-and I have high risk of postpartum depression or psychosis. But idk I still feel so fucking depressed back and fourth all the time. I can’t even work right now so everyone is working so hard to support me and I can’t even attempt to pull my own weight I feel so useless. I don’t even have a car anymore so I can’t even buy groceries with the money I don’t have. 

Everything feels so overwhelming and dark and I’m terrified. I also used to be heavy into weed and drinking but now I don’t even have that as a crutch to lean on, I miss being able to get high at least sometimes but I can’t with this pregnancy and I’m too scared that my baby will be taken away if I try to do it again so now it’s like a big ‘fuck you never again’ from the world. 

I just feel so hopeless and overwhelmed. Who knows if I’ll even survive childbirth, like my life lead up to just dying young. Even if that doesn’t happen I’m losing everything I know including my body too, I’m so scared of everything.  I’m losing my freedom, my body, my childhood, everything I knew, my pet, my coping mechanisms, I don’t even have money for my own place with my partner and probably won’t for years so I’ll have to raise her around my dad who doesn’t even want a baby in the house (he will love her and treat her well but isn’t willing to help much). And my partner can’t always work to support me so I’ll need to find a job too which is going to be so hard postpartum and I’m anxious about that too because last time I worked the stress from the job dropped me into an episode and I had to quit. Now I’m going to be doing it again just with lack of sleep and crazy hormones fucking me over-but I can’t let him just pull all the weight for all the money

I don’t even have motivation to play video games or do art anymore. I don’t even know what I do all day. I don’t even know what’s part of my bipolar or what’s part of the pregnancy anymore 

Thanks to anyone who read this whole thing. I’m just scared, and scared for my mental health, and I don’t know what to do. Yes I have a therapist. I just keep dropping into these moments that feel like the world is ending. Sometimes I’ll be more optimistic but right now I’m so anxious. I’m trying to learn better coping mechanisms and stuff but this is just a lot to take on all at once

title: Post rage episode spiral
content:
So...last night after my work party. I had bought myself a treat on the way home (joint* its legal here). I'm pretty broke right now (and always). So dropping $20 is pretty frivalous of me right now. When I got home I picked a dumbass fight with my partner about how I've been depressed. In me storming around the house i lost my bag from the dispensary.  I fully freaked out, like scary freak out. And the thing is is I had plenty of bud around so i wasnt like desperate to smoke, just desperate to find it. 

I literally was sobbing and flipped ky bed over, flipped my dresser over, pushed all the couches around, my partner is begging me to stop and i just fan't. I wound up slamming the door on an antique cabinet that HE LOVES, and cracked the glass. I feel like absolute shit. I feel like i get so destructive and its just not fair for the person i live with. I have broken so many things in anger. I have been medicated for almost 10 years and this doesnt happen much anymore, bu i never know what will set it off. I had had a 3 drinks at the office party, but honestly that doesnt usually make me aggro? 

Its now the next morning and im in a terrible spiral. Im so mad at myself, i dont know how my partner can stand me, and he still was hugging ne while i was sobbing on the floor.  Its just so dumb, i cant handle the shame and depression after an episode, it's just a reminder that while i might be managing this illness i'll always have it and have difficulty regulating emotions and it breaks my heart and feels so hopeless. 

Could really use help thinking of coping tactics to help calm down, or how people manage dealing post episode.

title: Out of touch with world events/news
content:
I’ve always felt kind of out of touch with what’s happening in the world. Sometimes I feel like.. looked down on by others because of this..? Like I’m uneducated and that I don’t care.. 
and I guess part of me doesn’t really care what’s going on because I have bipolar and I’m just trying to get by. I don’t have the space in me to follow the news. I didn’t even know it was Inauguration Day today and how that’s affecting so many people. I didn’t know about the fires in LA until last night because my bf brought it up. And I have no idea what’s happening in regards to Middle East conflicts. 

It’s not that I don’t care.. I’m just like.. trying to survive my own headspace? Like..? Yeah I don’t know the news… I have mixed episodes or I’m super depressed & can’t do anything or im in whatever rabbit hole my hypomania has me fixated on. Sometimes I feel bad cuz I’m a grown ass adult I should be more educated. But I just am not. And I know that’s very privileged of me to not be educated but it’s my truth. Anyone else relate or am I just an ignorant asshole lol? 
I feel like there’s a rhetoric in society to be as educated and aware about these issues in the world as we can.. which I understand and can appreciate that but I feel like when you’re mentally ill you may not have the space for that and that’s ok.

title: Depression is hurting my work performance
content:
I was never great at my job to begin with but I am dependable. I have ADHD that my psychiatrist won't treat with medication until she is sure my mania is under control so I am always in my head at work. A depressive episode started a few days ago and I am moving so slow. I am forgetful and constantly distracted by abusive internal thoughts. I feel like I can barely think. My coworkers are starting to get annoyed and I am worried I might get fired. They already have me training somebody else for my station and my hours got cut next week. This fucking disorder has ruined my head. I used to be smart and quick. Now I'm slow and stupid. 

This job has great benefits, time off, reasonable hours, and is generally accommodating which is hard to find in the food service industry. I was going to use it to move to another city by transferring to a new location but now it feels like my plans are fucked. I normally feel comforted by depressive episodes because I know I won't hurt people or myself like when I am manic. Now I am just stressed and dreading the next month since I know my episodes last awhile.

This fucking sucks.

title: Got diagnosed with bipolar type 2 yesterday, need some advice and support
content:
I'm 21, recently diagnosed. My boyfriend has bipolar type 1 and knows a lot about everything bipolar related and is just very worried about me and has basically nagged my ear off telling me I need to learn from other people that lives with it instead of just reading random studies and I agree with him. (Don't need to answer all my questions, even just something small would be very appreciated)

Basically what I wanna learn is strategies of how to keep track of symptoms and signs of an episode, how to keep safe when especially in a depressive episode but also with hypomania and mixed episodes too. 

I also wanna hear if any of you are dating someone that also have bp and have any tips on how to avoid triggering each others episodes. His is very severe and he can't take any medication but I started a medication last November due to me doing some real stupid stuff during a real bad depressive episode and that medication is working really well so far but it's still really important to know these kinda things y'know.

My boyfriend told me anger issues is comon with bp too and I didn't even know that and I've had issues with my anger my whole life so wanted to ask as well if there's any like symptoms or traits not many people talk about that could be good to learn about? I really don't know anything about mixed episodes either so I'm really clueless.

Also another thing I really wanna kinda teach myself is to handle the incredible shame I feel over how I acted in my latest episode that led to me being diagnosed.

If you have any advice or experience on any of these things I'd appreciate it a lot.

title: Tell me something good that’s happened to you lately !
content:
**Tell me something good that’s happened to you lately !**

I really need some good news in my life right now. Things have been so rough for so long that I’ve almost forgotten what happiness feels like. Every day feels like another pile of bad news—whether it’s in my own life or in the world around me.

Maybe it’s because I’m depressive and hypersensitive, but it all feels so overwhelming. I just want to hear something good for a change.

Even when I look beyond myself, it’s the same story. The news, social media, everything—it’s just one bad thing after another. The world feels so messed up.

So, I’m asking for some good news, something that’ll make me smile, even if it’s just for a moment. It doesn’t have to be big—maybe you got a good grade on a test, you enjoyed your favourite meal today, or you heard a joke so bad it was funny. Anything.

One good news to make me smile, just one good news.

title: What annoying symptoms made you realize you have Bipolar?
content:
I was recently diagnosed with bipolar disorder, and looking back, there were so many signs that I didn't fully recognize at the time. Now that I know more about the condition, I can connect the dots, but it was frustrating not understanding what was going on with me before.

Some of the symptoms that stood out the most:

1. **The energy rollercoaster**: I would go from feeling like I could conquer the world to barely being able to get out of bed for days. It felt like my energy levels were constantly betraying me.
2. **Impulsive decisions**: Whether it was spending too much money, starting a million projects, or saying things I regretted, I couldn’t understand why I acted so impulsively.
3. **Mood swings**: One moment, I’d be euphoric, talking non-stop, and feeling unstoppable, and the next, I’d sink into a pit of hopelessness. It was exhausting and made me question my own stability.
4. **Trouble sleeping**: I couldn’t sleep during manic phases no matter how hard I tried, and during depressive phases, all I wanted to do was sleep but still felt exhausted.
5. **Relationship challenges**: I often felt like my emotions were too much for the people around me, and I struggled with guilt after arguments or miscommunications.

Getting the diagnosis has been overwhelming but also a relief—I finally have an explanation for what’s been going on all these years. I’m curious: what symptoms made you realize you might have bipolar, or made others around you suggest getting help?

Any advice on how to navigate this diagnosis would be appreciated, too.It’s all still very new to me, and hearing from others who’ve been through this would mean a lot.

title: Working in mental health as a person diagnosed with bipolar disorder
content:
Hi friends!

This might be a bit niche, but I was hoping to hear from other people diagnosed with bipolar who work in mental health or adjacent fields. 

For background,  I'm almost 35 and I was diagnosed with bipolar at 16. Medicated and pretty much episode free outside of pregnancy and post-partum. It took until my mid-20s to really take it seriously and commit to a consistent medication regime and regular therapy. Doing so absolutely turned my life around after leaving a fair amount of chaos in my wake. I've also got that sweet ASD/OCD/CPTSD combo and some anxiety.

I work in an inpatient mental health setting and am currently applying for other mental health clinician jobs after finishing my degree in December. My question is - how do others protect their wellbeing when working with people experiencing mental health crises? Working in an acute setting I obviously see a lot of people in crisis. Like a lot of people with a trauma background/mental illness I have a lot of empathy and feel things quite deeply. Sometimes I sit with people whose story mirrors my own to some extent. 

Currently I have professional supervision and a session with my psychologist every month to talk through any scenarios that may have triggered me or feelings/emotions that have come up. I have good boundaries at work and I'm not projecting my shit on clients or anything, what I'm more concerned about is avoiding vicarious trauma and protecting my wellbeing. In my profession they talk about self-care a lot, but I'm not sure that a warm bath quite cuts it sometimes! 

Hope that makes sense! Looking forward to reading about everyone strategies.

He pointed out my mum making me my favorite Breqkfast is love. My brother looking out for me is love. My parents paying my uni fees is love. My best friend listening to me complain or yap is love. title: seeking advice for healing and growth

over the past year and a half, i’ve hurt friendships and relationships. i’ve tried to mend what i can, but i isolate so much when i’m depressed. i’ve spent days sobbing, with no love or motivation for anything. i’m glad i started new meds, but i know it’ll be a long journey. 

i ’ve also stopped using weed, which i realized was a crutch. it’s been almost three weeks, and while i’m committed to staying away, it’s been hard without that distraction. i’ve also been reflecting on my friendships and often feel like i’m the one in the wrong. this mindset has led me to lose friendships, and i have a lot of regrets. with job hunting and studying for a big exam, the next few months will be hard, but i want to get to the other side. if anyone has advice, i’d really appreciate it. im also 23!

title: The universe is out to get me
content:
I wonder why the universe is out to get me. I was born to crazy parents. My mother was an alcoholic, and we moved around constantly. We often just slept in the car. I never had the chance to make friends, moving from school to school.

When I was ten, I got a stepfather whom I loved. But by the time I was fifteen, my mother packed up the car and drove us to Oregon for some reason. In elementary school, no one liked me, and I have no idea why. I had no friends in Kingman, Arizona. When we moved to Mesa, I started hanging out with the stoners. We were all outcasts.

I've seen other people get opportunities, but I either got passed over or was too late. At one point, I lived in a house with my girlfriend's mother. She ended up in a mental hospital, and we couldn’t pay rent, so we got kicked out. While camping, the police showed up with guns, claiming someone reported that we were shooting at them. Of course, they didn’t find any guns.

Even now, life doesn’t seem to let up. My mother recently had a stroke. I tried to get to therapy, but my car broke down. I can’t rely on the bus because it takes too long, and our caretaker only works for four hours a day.

I even tried to share my feelings on a bipolar subreddit, but it wouldn’t let me in.

This sort of thing has been going on all my life.

Specifically, if we get into disagreements or, rather, if I spaz out about something he says / does that's otherwise harmless, nothing I say can remedy my wrongdoings. I either sound manipulative or whiny or am probably burying his feelings under my own.

For example, today, I'm not feeling well, and he wanted to come over. I said no, he said "FINE GUESS I'LL GO KMS".

And so I texted back, "Please, when we are disagreeing, don't joke about killing yourself. If this isn't a joke, please go to a hospital. But otherwise, please don't joke about that because it makes me want to say yes to anything to make sure you're happy and safe."

He apologized, said he thought we were just joking back and forth and he didn't realize I was genuinely not feeling well.

I said it was okay... And it *was* okay on his end. But it's not at all okay because of me...

I asked if he was okay, and he said he was, but now I'm scared he's lying because he's afraid of telling me the truth. And I don't blame him. I must seem unstable. I want to tell him he could tell me anything because it's true, but what if he doesn't trust me to hear his emotions?

I tried to backpedal and apologize because I missed his joke. But he said it was okay, and I didn't want to beat a dead horse and say "but are you okay" when he said he was. I don't believe him. I think I've hurt him.

And so now I can't ask if he's okay again because he may think I'm annoying. And if he thinks I'm annoying he won't tell me the truth. And then I'm burying his emotions despite that being the whole reason of me asking if he's okay, to make sure he doesn't have to bury his emotions. So then I stay silent and try to move on but I'm so scared he is hurting because of me but I can't ask because then the above will happen.

Everything I say, and want to say, is always wrong.

He deserves so much more than me...

title: predromal psychosis signs in comparison to mania
content:
hey bipolar people. I'm diagnosed bipolar type 1 and have been since the age of 15 due to my response to anti-depressants and my family history of the disorder.
With my understanding bipolar disorder does tend to awaken a little more around late teens/early adulthood.

As well as my bipolar type 1 diagnosis I have some of that adhd in me, so l'm all over the place. Around six months ago I was put on adhd medication to hopefully counteract my never ending avolition associated with my bipolar and adhd.

I would like to put preface on the fact that I am a very high-functioning bipolar and have an extreme level of self-awareness, therefore I am keen to recognizing my warning signs of episodes, etc.
Recently I've started to notice some strange things.

I've always had spurts of paranoia, or disconnections from reality, however I've never experienced something quite like this.
Over the past few months my days have been blending together, I don't have recollection of days previous of the present, and time doesn't feel real.

I don't know if anyone else will genuinely understand this feeling, but I feel as if due to my bipolar disorder I am very prone to being triggered by stress. During times of high stress I tend to disconnect, everything around me becomes foggy, I'm having a hard time understanding what people are trying to say to me, my vision morphs, and I start developing delusions.

This feels as if it is a more consistent and nagging feeling. Based on my understanding, this could be early warning signs of psychosis; which is why I am mentioning predromal psychosis. I also tend to have spurts of paranoia at night. I refuse to sleep without my door locked.
I've also been very negligent to spending time with family & people, I find that I get irritated quickly, and would much rather be alone.

I feel as if there are bits and pieces of an episode of psychosis, or a severe episode of mania slowly seeping through the cracks.
Why l'm posting here is because l'm curious on what people's warning signs are, or how they may have felt before headed into psychosis/mania.

I have experienced manic episodes before, however psychosis is something that I have not experienced yet, and I know with my condition and family history I am very prone to it.

So questions are:

What were the few days/weeks like leading up to your psychosis?

What are some warning signs you later on recognized to be your warning signs of an episode of mania/psychosis?

title: Hang in there, life gets really good!

I lost a career, relationships, family ties and more. It was brutal.

But it's not all bad news. Bipolar has helped me be very creative, to have nervous excitement in the best and the worst of times, but also have the ability to help others and be an advocate.

There are super tough days, sure, but I'm now living happy and healthy after years of struggle. I guess this is a post to say to hang in there, ride out the tough days, because life gets really really good!

title: How to tell if medication stopped working?
