I have been having really intense depressive episodes with psychosis, that last for a day or two, then go away for a couple days, then come back, then go away. It's been a week and a half, everything was great for years and then they weren't. It only lasts a couple days at a time, but even when it "goes away," I definitely am still feeling unmotivated and detached.

The episodes definitely remind me of my bipolar depression/mixed episodes back in early 2019. But I'm experiencing more psychosis than I remembered having before.... It is definitely not BPD. I know what borderline mood swings and splitting feels like, and it's always caused by some conflict or stressor. This isn't caused by anything I can put my finger on, and it's about 100x more intense. It's not emotional distress, it's full blown numbness, not able to feel love, being annoyed/angry at my family, delusional, feeling like all of my loved ones are manipulating me, can't get out of bed/eat/shower kind of stuff. Is this typical for medication failure?

I have a psychiatry appointment next week, so I'm waiting as patiently as possible for that. I hope to try a medication adjustment, but I am curious if you all have any anecdotal experiences or feedback on what to pay attention to/how to cope for now. Thanks.

title: BP1 can make it all come crashing down: What I tell myself to cope.
content:
If you have experienced manic episodes due to BP1, you want to live a normal life but the possibility of having a manic episode at any time makes it hard to live without fear. The fear, in turn, makes it hard to live a normal life. 

So I've been finding things to tell myself to cope with this reality. This list is by no means conclusive, but it has been working for me so far so I thought I'd share it, in case anyone is curious or may benefit.

1. If you're not manic right now, find a way to enjoy it. You're healthy, at this time! Enjoy! This can mean merely living in the present and finding joy in that. The fact that you know what it's like to be sick/manic may make you appreciate the moments of wellness even more. Also, please don't let myself ruin those moments of wellness with fear for the future. It's wasting a good thing :)

2. If you do have a manic episode, it may really suck and your life can be burnt to ashes. But you can always rebuild! Always. You have before and you'll do it again. You may not end up leading the life you imagined you'd lead but who really does, anyway? 

3. Another redditor u/FunTone6524 said to me that your life can never be fully ruined due to a manic episode. This was a revelation to hear and consistent with my experiences. Following my manic episodes, I experienced a lot of suffering and while certain things were ruined, many valuable things remained and were even strengthened (like my relationship with my family, who showed up for me). That insight gave me some comfort and relief. There will always be things of value left behind after a manic episodes. 

4. We are not alone. There are so many of us. Experiencing this illness and this pain. That makes me feel love for all of us and makes the struggle seem less daunting, because we're all in it together. I feel connected to others who experience this illness in a way that makes me feel a strong sense of kinship.

  
5. I don't compare myself to others who are without bipolar and "healthier." This is where my studies in Buddhism have been helpful. I've tried to "let go" of my attachment of comparing myself to others, because that attachment is unhealthy and leads me to feelings of dread. I focus on myself. "Letting go" in other areas has also proven healthy. For example, I've let go of my attachment to the life I wanted to lead. It didn't happen. It probably wasn't possible. It was a construct. My life is my life, nothing less and nothing more, and all I can do it make the most of it, as much as I am able to.

  
That's all for now! But I plan to refine this list over time and add to it. I'd love to hear some thoughts, if you're willing. My best to you and your lives.

It feels unnatural, like reading cringey texts between your friend and their boyfriend. It reads “I miss you pookie bear ” and you want to throw up in your mouth a little, but you get it. Except this time, I’m in the texts. I’m dating someone whose history with me doesn’t even feel like my own.

I try not to be a bad person. I explain this pattern in new relationships because once I recognized it, I realized it was cruel. So I thought explaining it would make it easier, that if they knew, they would understand and understanding would change things. But it doesn’t. Understanding doesn’t make it easier and it doesn’t obligate anyone to stay.

Now, I have to bang my head through drywall when he’s not platonic but romantic in our romantic non-platonic relationship. I’ve stayed by him so he wasn’t alone once and he’s re-payed me by being an amazing boyfriend, just so I could complain about how hard it is that he loves me on Reddit. 

I’ve been so unkindly distant. When he said, “I wish we could cuddle right now,” because we’re on opposite ends of the country for the weekend, I replied, “It’s nice to cuddle when it’s cold outside,”. I avoided pronouns and turned feelings into a fact to avoid intimacy.

I haven’t fallen out of love. I’m just struggling with this bizarre feeling of waking up in a relationship that feels both mine and not mine. I have shiny new legs but I don’t know how to walk. I don’t want to end things regardless of my feelings because he, more than anyone I’ve ever met, does not deserve an ounce of cruelty. I just don’t know how to do this and I wish he could have started loving me now and not before.

title: ever since my diagnosis i’ve been insecure
content:
F20. posting on reddit because i’ve got nobody else. actually i do have people they just don’t know so i feel awfully alone. 

i got diagnosed last december, but i was on meds since last july. antipsychotics, mood stabilizer, then an anti depressant since last october . i didn’t notice it at first, but i gained a lot of weight. gained a whopping 12kgs. i just can’t stop eating, especially at night. i tried intermittent fasting, chia seeds, even pills— they don’t work. i also try to run and do pilates but i don’t feel like they are working. i look at the mirror and i feel sad. 

i keep getting taunted by some relatives and people at school about my weight gain, and the hard part is i can’t even say that it’s because of my medication because i want this diagnosis a secret. especially from the judging eyes of my family. my dad doesn’t even know. only mom does (she is very supportive at least) i’ve only told my closest friend, and i can’t tell her my weight gain problems because she is a person who recovered from an eating disorder so i do not want to trigger her. 

i’m doing my best to stay consistent with my medications despite my insecurities, but it’s hard not to blame them for the changes in my body. part of me wants to stop taking them altogether, but i know going cold turkey isn’t safe. 

my psychological evaluation came with an IQ test and let me tell you something my score was an absolute punch to the gut. with brass knuckles. made me realize that all those time i felt capable, i felt and believed i was smart— it was all because i’m ill. not because i really am. i wasn’t great, i was just under the influence of hypomania. 

i’m an awfully ambitious person and i knew i was going to achieve great things i could feel it in my bones this surge of power that i could do everything and leave a positive mark in the world. i really thought i was something. i thought i was going to be someone. but my diagnosis and iq test went out of its way and stamped ‘AVERAGE’ on my forehead with big bold letters in red. 

i don’t know. maybe i’ll get over this soon but all this really humbled me to the core. i just feel hopeless. now i lost my entire confidence— physically and mentally. academically. everything. i just want to stay in my room and rot. wait for some miracle helicopter to pick me up and fix all my problems for me. i’m an absolute mess. 

my biggest problem right now is my weight gain. my clothes do not fit anymore like legit i had to spend all my christmas money on clothes i went from a medium to L-XL. i don’t know what to do anymore. any advice? 

also just to clarify, i’m not in some sort of in denial with my diagnosis and mad at it. i’m glad i got diagnosed, i can finally understand myself somehow. but this is just difficult a bit. i know others have it worse. it’s just quite difficult

title: Wrote a decent short horror story poem while hypo today
content:
The Bone Orchard 

In the valley where shadows breathe,
Beneath a sky that cannot grieve,
There grows an orchard, pale and stark,
Its roots entwined in ashen dark.

Each tree is twisted, brittle, bare,
With skeletal fingers that claw the air,
And fruits that glimmer, soft and cold,
A thousand lifetimes trapped in gold.

I wandered there, through whispered wails,
Past winds that carried ghostly trails,
And felt the earth beneath my feet,
Pulse with a slow, uneasy beat.

The orchard spoke, in tongues unknown,
Of buried flesh and fractured bone,
Of dreams it drank, of deaths it sowed,
Of endless lives it had bestowed.

A single fruit hung low and near,
Its glow a call, its voice severe.
"Take, and taste, and see the whole,
The truth of life within the soul."

I reached, I plucked, I bit, I wept,
As visions bloomed where silence crept.
A child I was, then old and gray,
Then dust upon the winds' ballet.

Each death, each end, played out in turn,
My body ash, my spirit burned.
Yet here I stood, a man once more,
Lost in the orchard's cursed lore.

The trees now leaned, their hunger vast,
Each root a grave of lives amassed.
The fruits began to pulse and glow,
A harvest ripe for souls to sow.

I dropped the fruit, its golden skin,
And felt it rot beneath my sin.
But still its taste was in my veins,
A hymn of loss, a song of pain.

And as I fled, the orchard sighed,
Its shadows whispered where I’d died.
For every step I took away,
Another tree began to sway.

Now I see it, behind closed eyes,
Its branches scrape at blackened skies.
The Bone Orchard grows, it cannot cease—
It feeds on death, and it will feast.

title: Missed out…possible trigger
content:
It was a cold and stormy night when I was 16, and ran away from home. I went from living in my stepmothers super strict, but responsible household to utter chaos, food insecurity, and being the caregiver for my younger step siblings. 

My step father couldn’t read, and could barely write. My mother was bed bound most of the time with her bi-polar. I was responsible for everything-writing checks for utility bills, school notes, staying home to babysit if my siblings were sick.

One summer day I found myself in front of the bathroom mirror watching my arm weep. It wasn’t my first self harm incident, but definitely the worse. I don’t remember how, or doing it, but reality had to be dealt with so I called my mom at work.

I ended up in the psych ward for 6 months. I missed homecoming, my friends, school. I was diagnosed with ’manic depression’ and ‘obsession with death’. I was an 80’s goth, so yeah, whatever. When I went back, kids thought it was ‘cool’. Of course it wasn’t. 

Today I was watching a teenage movie and I saw so many things I missed out on. I had always pretended I was too cool to do things like prom, senior pictures, sports games, school dances for holidays. 

I think now I was embarrassed because of my illness, because of my family situation (being poor), and just being shy. My bipolar and anxiety made me too nervous to be around all those people. Girls were ordering prom dresses from catalogs to be tailored. I was trying to figure out if I was going to have a good day (mania) or be depressed and bed bound like my mother. 

High school was hard enough being poor, but having mood swings was even worse. I got in a lot of fights, wasn’t shy about sex, drinking, and self harm. 

At 53, I still have self inflicted scars, scars I let other people give me, and enough memories I once thought were good times, but were really end results of my illness. 

It’s not easy being young and sick. Try to take stories that other people share and use them as evidence to try to curtail negative behaviors.

title: DEALING WITH BEING BIPOLAR: AN INVISIBLE BATTLE
content:
Please, im really looking for some outsider-bipolar-eyes in that existencial crises. I feel alone. 

I'm always on and off meds. My most recently and stable experience was taking moods stabilizers for about 2 years. and it did kinda stabilized me BUT I went into a more "lowered" state and the highs became rusty and very few. My emotions became less explosive, but I  felt heavy. The truth is that I still had crises and depressed phases, even with medication. I stopped a few months ago and in a way I feel better----- I'm in a stable moment, I've been in therapy for years and I'm already 30+, so, relatively safe, I felt the need to "get to know myself" and stopped the medication .

Anyway, just like in the medication era, I have crises and mood swings, but now with more intensity both ways and more "highs", even a few days with hypomania. 
But im still TIRED with the inconstancy and all the WEIGHT of dealing with this shit, even more so feeling so alone and unseen, I'm thinking about going to the psychiatrist again but for what? Nothing ever "resolves" and it even gets worse. Lately, at least I've been more productive during hypomanic crises and I'm still "stable", so why change that? 

But i have this URGE get better, to function, to be helped, saved or stroke by a fucking miracle. Somedays are unbearable. One day i can barely get out bed, take a shower or work and one day I wake up feeling like a force of nature, with so much energy it actually hurts and i have to do something to let it out a bit or i'll explode. Its hard to make plans, to keep relationships, its hard to work, to live and the worst part is: We are either labeled as CRAZY or we're just NOT taken seriously. And i dont know which is worse. 

 I feel that bipolarity is living camped on the precipice, always at the mercy of external circumstances and with the feeling of being "one circumstance away" from going completely bat shit crazy, or "one sleep away" from walking up and finding out you lost everything. We don't always get real support in the health area, especially if we can't invest a lot of money in it, at the same time we struggle mentally, we still have to try our best to keep our jobs, pay the bills and still maintain relationships, the house, ourselves.... I always feel overwhelmed, having to manage my external and internal life. I'm always apologizing, justifying myself, sometimes having to lie because the truth is just too crazy, incomprehensible or pathetic. The amont of energy spent on masking, trying to improve, improving, and falling again - Its a rollercoster. And it's an invisible battle. Anyway, just a rant. I'm tired of being like this. I just wanted to have more money ans stability to have all the necessary psychological and psychiatric support, to no longer need to adapt to a world dynamic that I don't fit into and to be able to focus on my art. Until this miracle happens, I'm exhausted.

PS: At the same time i hate being like that, i also LOVE the magic in bipolar and maybe one day i will post a tribute too all the "perks and blessings" that came with this curse. But today im just tired.

title: Embracing the Good in Bipolar
content:
Hi everyone,

I (40F) wanted to share some of the positives I’ve experienced with bipolar disorder. It’s easy to focus on the struggles, but there are moments where it’s brought growth and creativity into my life.

For me, mania has fueled creativity. During a tough manic episode, I freestyle rapped about my experiences, which helped me release some intense emotions and even brought laughter in a hard time.

Journaling has been another key tool for me. I gift journals to others to encourage creativity and healing, and looking back on my own entries has shown me just how much I’ve healed. I try to focus on the positive, but I’ve also learned to leave space for the tough stuff as I work through it in therapy. It’s about balance.

I’d love to hear from others—have you found any positives in your personal experience with bipolar? Whether it’s creativity, growth, or something else, I think it’s important to recognize the good alongside the challenges.

Thanks for reading.

“I am tired of everything being something. I am tired of every single thing provoking every single emotion. If I were dead, this all would be nothing. I want nothing…” - a segment from a note I wrote called “The Grey”.

title: Behavior in a slump
content:
Does anyone else have an urge that tells you to cut off/cut contact with everyone you know except maybe family and be completely alone again when you're in a down phase? I'm quite introverted and I think it's my brain trying to reduce stress but I resist it because I believe it would be a self-destructive mistake to do so. This down phase I believe was triggered by my college spring semester starting up and the mental preparation of having a workload again, and every time the urge comes I try to fight it off and not do anything rash like that until my mood curves up again and I'm thinking clearly.

For additional context, I've moved on from quite a few friend groups over the years and view myself as somewhat of a 'social nomad' if that makes sense. I think I'm a good guy and people like having me around but I always feel like if I disappeared and went alone again, they'd be able to find someone new or become fine again after a time. I know this thinking might be flawed or counter to how they or I might feel when it actually happens, but I also can't help but think how peaceful my life would be again if I didn't interact with anyone.

Curious if anyone shares this experience or something similar, thanks.

title: First manic episode

title: is it common to experience a symptom later down your diagnosis ?
content:
I’ve been diagnosed with BPD for the past 4 years now and just recently with bipolar 1 so I’ve been navigating that it’s still very new to me but a common symptom I hadn’t truly experienced were hallucinations I suppose, on occasion when I am sleep deprived it’d occur but that seemed pretty straight forward to me 

and then I am also a generally paranoid person give anxieties and all but these days as in the past 2 weeks, it’s been a back and forth juggle I guess of trying to manage my symptoms that suddenly started popping up out of nowhere 

Now they aren’t aggressive but they’re definitely prominent, to start off, it’s felt like how you can feel someone is staring at the back of your head or the presence of another person by your side but it’s been this constant pressure I nearly want to rip my back off !! 

in the light, when I went out over the weekend my vision was warping and it felt uneasy like anything and everything was waiting for me to lose my guard and jump back out at me 

 I’ve been anticipating this fright, I check the peep hole of my door and it feels like someone’s hiding to where I can’t see them through it and will pop back out at me 

and another, possibly minor thing is that when I was listening to music with nothing else going on 

No Tv, no game, no nothing 

I could actively hear a man speaking to me through the screen even if in the music I was listening to had no instance of that

Basically my ask is, has anyone developed something they’ve never experienced in their diagnosis before ? 

My therapist has mentioned schizophrenia as my older brother has it but I haven’t had any suspicions of it as I feel it isn’t nearly as debilitating as it was for him, so our second was psychosis which is likely or just general paranoia but it’s been a horrible feeling

title: I've been stable over a year
content:
I've been stable over a year now. Maybe close to 2 years? I haven't had a "manic episode" for almost 4 years now. There's been a few moments when my psych thought I was veering toward hypomania or greater depression (my baseline leans depressed) and either made a med adjustment or let me ride it out to see where it went and I was fine. 

I take a mood stabilizer and a well known ndri. every morning. I cycle thru phases where I take an antipsychotic. 

I don't want to be on medication anymore. I know this is probably a very common thought amongst those of us that have experienced long periods of stability, but I am beginning to doubt I have bipolar or had any symptoms to begin with. When I think back I feel like I must have been exaggerating or it feels like a dream version of me, or maybe my environmental circumstances were putting me in such a stressful position that anyone would've snapped. I was so much younger as well, a lot can change between your early 20s and late 20s. 

I want to ask my psych about coming off meds. Has anyone ever done this successfully? They probably aren't in this subreddit, but anyone gone off meds and realized they didn't actually ever have bipolar and instead just have cptsd or something? 

(My girlfriend was originally diagnosed with bipolar as well, but diagnosis changed to depression, anxiety, and adhd and now she's on the same ndri, an ssri, and a stimulant and doing better than ever. I already know that a certain ssri gives me debalititating panic attacks but also I'm like what if that wasn't real?)

Ok yes I know I am such a stereotype I've just been ok for so long I'm like I don't want to have bipolar anymore, this was obviously a mistake.

This illness doesn't define us.

title: I always cry after sex but only during depressive episodes
content:
I've been dating my boyfriend for four months and told him early on about my bipolar disorder. During my manic episodes, I stayed awake for days refusing to leave our 24/7 campus building, crashing and repeating for a month, spent impulsively on expensive gifts even though he asked me not to, hyper-sexual, and pushed for constant time together until he made a schedule for us. 

Through it all he's always been patient and supportive, never making me feel like he was "dealing" with my mental illness.


Recently, I've been in a depressive episode. I've been crying to the point of panic attacks, plagued by irrational fears that he's cheating on me or hates me, and continuously asking him if he's upset with me.

We had sex for the first down since this episode and I broke down and couldn't stop sobbing afterward. He rubbed my back as I hiccuped because I wasn't breathing.

After, I tried to explain that this happens.
Sex just feels overwhelming because of the emotional intensity and high and the "come down" afterward is more intense because of the depressive episodes, I'm not sure if that explanation is accurate.

He comforted me until I stopped but later when he asked to talk I said not right now. That night, he didn't cuddle me and turned away. In the morning, I asked if he was upset with me over last night and he said he just wanted to give me space. 

I feel soo embarrassed and apologetic about the whole situation and I doubt we’ll be having sex for a while.

title: SATURDAY DISCLOSURE DISCUSSION 🗣️
content:
**Happy Saturday!**

A common question that comes up is, *'How do I tell people I have bipolar disorder?'*. Do you disclose at work? To close friends and family? Or are you telling the whole world? title: Anxiety
content:
I’ve been waking up with intense anxiety every morning for the past week, and it’s exhausting me. It eases as the day goes on, but it ruins my ability to function and causes me to mess up everything I try to do, which then increases the anxiety the next morning.

I’m doing my best to cope with it. I try to avoid the bad habits I have when I’m anxious. Instead, I start the day with pushups and stretching, I write, listen to music, and audiobooks… But it just seems to be getting worse every day.

The only silver lining is that since I’ve finally managed to keep a diary, I have a better understanding of the passage of time, and I think this might be related to messing up my meds. I’ve slowly been getting back on them, and the latest one I started a week and a half ago. Hopefully, this is just a side effect and it passes before it leads to depression. title: Loss of empathy?
content:
Do you lose empathy for others during an episode?

I've recently shared with my partners and family that I go through periods of time where I feel almost zero empathy for others, even close family and friends. I would describe it as being almost psychopathic. No empathy, guilt, remorse. Plus I will "mask" by acting the same way I would normally. 

Apparently, I'm good at pretending, because no one had any idea I was doing it. To them I seem more irritable, but not apathetic. I pretend, because I know I'll cause damage to my life if I act as I'm actually feeling. Obviously, it doesn't always work, but so far I haven't done any lasting damage to my relationships. 

When I asked people in my life if this was something they experienced, none of them had. Even my sister who also has bipolar hasn't. Is this unusual or just something those in my circle don't experience?

title: How many people know in your life / at work?
content:
We have “random” drug screenings at work and I (30f) have been tested three times in the last 18 months. The computer is supposed to pull 5 “random” names from the pool of over 5,000 employees and yet my name has been pulled thrice and there are people who have worked for 10 years and never have had one (I’ve been there a little over four)
The coworkers I’m close(ish) to think it’s due to me having normal weeks and being friendly and helpful and then out of nowhere everything changes and I’m either snapping at people for not getting things done or I will go an entire week without talking to anyone and excusing myself to have panic attacks in the bathroom.
No one at my company knows that I’m bipolar and I’m starting to wonder if maybe I have that conversation with someone (like my boss that I have a very good relationship with) in order to explain that I’m not doing any illegal drugs.

I’ve heard success stories but also horror stories about sharing that part of one’s life so I’m just looking to gather some more info and hope it’ll help me make a good decision

TLDR: No one at work knows I’m bipolar but should I share that with my boss so he’s aware and hopefully I stop getting “random” drug tested by HR for the “suspicious and odd changes in my mood throughout the months”?

title: How do you get over regret and guilt over something you did while manic?
content:
I don’t know what to do.

I, 19F, got diagnosed about a month ago. I did something very terrible which led my long term ex to breakup with me, which was worsened by a total meltdown and spiral that happened during our final confrontation. The breakup became messy and he’s telling everyone about what happened which led to me seeking help professional help. After a few weeks of therapy, I got recommended to see a psychiatrist which eventually led to me finding out i was bipolar.

To this day, I still think about what happened. I’m trying to move on and focus on myself because I know nothing I do now will fix what happened. The part that pains me is that I’m enduring this battle alone, when I know it in me that he should have been the person to help me through it. He would’ve been the one reminding me to take care of myself, eat my meals, take my meds, and ask me how I was doing mentally. That on top of the emotional dependency I had on my ex makes this moving on process even worse. Now, he’s gone “living his best life” and endlessly talking shit about me.

I met someone recently who is so nice and kind and selflessly sent me “just because flowers and gifts” as a way of showing appreciation to me. He is partner material, he really is. While I have established boundaries that we are just friends, everytime I look at him, all I am reminded of is that my ex should have been that person.

Any advice on how to get over this? I am just someone who’s trying to navigate university, adulting, life, love, loss, and bipolarfuckingdisorder all at once. I’d really want to hear from someone who has had, not necessarily the same, but similar shitty life experiences.

title: We don’t have childhood pictures bc of me
content:
When I was having a manic psychotic episode a couple years ago I threw out a usb. I forgot at the time that all of our family pictures were on it and by the time I came back down it was long gone:-( my grandmother used to be the family picture person but she passed away and I took it upon myself to make sure I saved them. I did this before I knew I was this sick, I thought I just had unipolar depression. Had no idea I was capable of becoming psychotic. I also have lost my granny’s family recipes :-( I forgot where I put them and they have never been found. I remember I put them somewhere very special for protection then forgot where that was after many episodes and medication changes. I never imagined I’d do something so stupid. 

If I would have known that i could potentially do these things I would have given them all to someone else. I feel like I cannot be trusted with anything precious:-( I might have a delusion that will cause me to throw it away or memory so bad that I’ll never be able to locate said items again. I also cannot afford to maintain a storage unit in another state with handwritten love letters from my grandpa to grandfather after she passed. I have no ability to dig for things before I lose the unit. I am the family liability. I used to be the logical and sure-footed one. Things change so much with this disorder, I don’t even know who I am anymore. Thanks for reading and letting me share. I hope you don’t feel the same.

There have been a few little nudges since but they were all quickly managed with careful sleep/activity adjustments or a small meds adjustment. I've made it almost 2 years since an attempt. Almost a year since any meaningful harm. I'm excelling in the nursing school I started, with top scores for my level 1 exams. My work loves me and keeps trying to get me to go full time (I'm very part time because of school and kids). But it always lurks, and right now it feels too close.

So often my episodes start this time of year, frequently after travel I do annually. My meds are great, but even so. There's music that's so distractingly loud in my head that I can't get anything done until I listen and dance. Over and over. I'm irritable and restless. I'm leaning hard on my as-needed meds for sleep. Urges come back and get stronger. I'll be singing and dancing with my kid one minute and snapping at them to leave me alone the next. I'll get through it. I always do. And it won't be as bad as before. But I'm worried it's back. The music is never a good sign, as amazing as it feels sometimes.

(Yes, I'm working with my providers. We're trying a med tweak that I just don't think is working, and then we'll try another. I'm open with my therapist. Etc.)

title: Antipsychotic killed my creativity and spirituality - how to restore?
content:
Reposting this, with the medication name removed

—

Antipsychotic killed my creativity and spirituality - how to restore?

My doctors prescribed me Antipsychotic in May 2023 due to mania. I was on the drug from May to roughly August 2023. 

I noticed around August/September that my spirituality was diminished; my x5 daily prayers didn’t feel the same anymore. (I’m Muslim, I pray 5 times a day). The prayer is what I enjoyed the most. 

I quit the drug cold turkey around September of that year, and my prayer quality came back. From Sept 2023 to Dec 2023, I was not taking the Antipsychotic mg consistently; I did notice it gave me excellent sleep, though, so I I took it occasionally in this timeframe. I was also able to write songs during this timeframe as my creativity was still intact. 

In December 2023, I took the drug on one occasion, and my brain felt “wiped out” the next day; the spiritual and creative stuff was totally gone. I also started experiencing cognitive dulling during December/January 2023, a little bit. 

My doctor put me back on the AP in February 2024, and I was taking it until October 2024. In October, he tapered it slowly over 2 months until Dec 2024, when I was completely off it. 

It’s been 6 weeks now, and the creativity and spirituality has not come back. Have I injured my brain, in how I abruptly quit the drug in September 2023, and then took it occasionally? My doctor wouldn’t listen to me then or provide me with tapering instructions so I quit myself back then.

Has the antipsychotic damaged my brain, in this specific context? Any suggestions on how I can get my spiritually & creativity back?

title: realized i am manic and need reassurance
content:
i recently realized i am in an episode and am completely freaking out. broke up with my partner impulsively (kind of, was having previous thoughts but i believe they were triggered by mania) and we tried to stay intimate in certain ways (stupid i know, but i didnt want to lose him all at once). then he told me he couldnt keep being intimate at a very inopportune time as i was freaking out about other things and i went ballistic (i also have bpd so the abandonment fear and feelings of loneliness kicked in). i left very impulsively to stay with someone in a different city to get away from everything (very unlike me, i hate traveling and had never taken a train before but suddenly just up and left the next day). started cutting again. the hysterics went on for a few days, begging him not to leave, accusing him of things, constantly asking for reassurance, etc. all seemed ok (well not okay as i was acting terribly but it seemed we could pull through, he was telling me he loved me and could give me reassurance, etc) until he texted me a very long paragraph about how how i behaved was "beyond him" and he was very disappointed in how i had acted that i had crossed/pushed his boundaries and he needs space (he also said later in the message he doesnt think we should talk anymore which is a bit confusing, does he need space or is he completely gone?)

i'm fucking heartbroken. i know what i did was wrong but as we all know it is very hard to stop when you start. i feel so ashamed, my last episode of this kind was a year ago and this relationship was so much healthier and i never thought this would happen. i go to an incredibly small school, very intwined social circles, we basically live a stones throw away and he was my closest friend. we had an incredible bond and i ruined it. i am constantly shaking, feelings of impending doom and so physically upset that i feel i might die or am in immediate danger, i cant imagine my life from the next moment. 

all i can think is, why me? why did i have to be cursed with this disease, one that is so incurable and that will never leave me and ruins my life over and over and over, where i know there is never an end? i struggle with this a lot but now more than ever. i know it is genetic but i do not know anyone in my family who is like me, i feel like this is a curse or karma of some kind. i know its my fault for how i acted. i know i have to get better, i am setting up therapy appointments, calling my psych to increase my meds, i called 988 to try to work through it. i am so, so scared he will never speak to me again. my whole life has upended in a matter of days, its not just the breakup, i also quit a position in an organization that i had held for 2 years very quickly and obviously the train ride decision, spending money i dont have, cutting for the first time in a year.

he is supposed to come pick up his stuff and talk in an hour. i am going to try my hardest to keep it together, tell him i was manic without using it as an excuse and then give him space. do people think he could forgive me? i could use some commiseration about the experience and people who relate. i feel like my life is over even as i try to set myself up for success while getting care. how do people deal with knowing there is no cure for bipolar? how do you deal with knowing sometimes, you just lose control and no one has to forgive you? i am trying to reach out for help but it feels like i am so alone.

title: "Overcoming Adversity" - Grad School Application Essay
content:
I plan on applying for a master's program, and I'm lowkey freaking out about the rec letters and essays.  I need 3 letters of recommendation, a statement of purpose, an essay on "overcoming adversity," and an essay on "unique circumstances."  

Background:

  
I have a couple huge blemishes on my transcript... my first semester of college I had a severe episode of depression which led to me dropping out and getting W's for all my courses.  During the tail-end of the depression, I took a workshop on meditation that was supposed to help me with anxiety and depression, but instead I developed what was diagnosed as conversion disorder (now known as functional neurological disorder) stemming from repressed childhood trauma.  I was physically disabled/unable to work/attend school for over a year. 

When my symptoms were more under control, I started back up at community college and after a few years transferred back to the university I dropped out from.  My last year and a half at the university, I again had severe depression that resulted in getting bad grades and also distancing myself from the professors who would be writing me letters of rec. I haven't spoken to them since before I graduated which was 5 years ago... This latter depressive episode I feel is harder to write off and may have ruined my chances for success

TLDR: I have blemishes on the first semester and last 3 semesters of my undergrad transcript and burned bridges with potential letter of rec writers thanks to depressive episodes

I'm afraid of being stigmatized if I tell the truth/go into any sort of detail.  How could I frame this?  What sorts of details could I share without instant rejection?  Does anyone have any personal experiences on grad school essays of this type that they'd be willing to share?  Thanks for any suggestions in advance <3

title: Should I switch to a different therapist?
content:
Hey so I’m in a little bit of a pickle. I just got diagnosed with bipolar, and there’s a lot of emotions that come with that but I can’t shake the feeling that I really don’t think my therapist is good for me but I can’t tell if this is just me over reacting so here’s just what’s going on 
1) I am constantly triggered in therapy. Accusations and judgment gets under my skin a lot. Every time I’m trying to open up about different traumatic events that have left my brain scrambled, her first question is always “what did you do to deserve it?” “Did you do something wrong first and this was just the reaction?” Which I’m sure happens but I end up spending most of the appointment defending myself and explaining all the events before hand. Example: I was dealing with a creep at work and she seemed confident that I must have been flirting with him. I know for sure that the second I met him I got weird vibes and immediately started avoiding him as much as possible (I have a lot of trauma with men) so I know I never led the guy on
2) my dad is also her client and he doesn’t like me much. Love but not like. My mom’s abusive and has untreated bipolar and my dad is the enabler. Because I always spoke up about something needing to be done about the situation and he has shut me up saying that everything’s fine. He hates accountability and will blame everyone but himself. And I can’t shake the feeling that my therapist is in some way taking his side. When came to my childhood trauma he likes to say I lie or exaggerate things while I was literally begging for help. It just seems like my therapist doesn’t believe me at all
3)she and my dad are strict catholic conservatives so sometimes therapy sometimes takes a weird controlling direction where she wants to discuss politics, she make condescending remarks about my dyed hair and band t-shirts. Asks about me dressing modestly and sex life. Like always sees me as a degenerate of some sort and doesn’t respect any my personal life choices saying that her office is a place for her to practice her faith freely. I’m not anti religious but I really don’t respect the weird “you got to live your life exactly like mine” stuff
4) the only helpful advice I have gotten so far is how to properly set up a boundary. Everything else seems to be her desperately trying to catch me in something to prove her bias. She looks dead inside until she suddenly gets excited and exclaims something a long lines of “I got you now!” Or “you can’t fool me” and then cue the accusation and my explanation of how “no I didn’t do that. This is what I did” and it takes every inch of my being to stay calm because I feel like I never get to problem solving
This is getting to the point where I’m wondering if I’m even bipolar but I’m not medicated yet and it could be just my view of the situation but I’m pretty sure I’m being as honest as possible. I’m just super confused and anxious right now

title: How do you manage driving anxiety?
content:
First post so bear with me… I am 21F, so I’ve had my license for quite some time and I’d like to think I’m a good driver, but sometimes while I’m depressed I get so mindlessly detached. I know to, and do, focus really, really hard on following the rules of the road. I’ve never been in an accident or even close to one, but every time I get into the car depressed I think about the worst. Just very very scared the whole time behind the wheel. It’s gotten to the point where I’ll just stay home if I’m too anxious about it (terrible cyclical pattern of self isolating). I feel like I don’t have enough faith in my driving skills even though I am a perfectly capable driver— anyone else feel this way or is it just me? 

And then there’s the manic side of the coin. I don’t experience the “I’m invincible” symptom, so I know not to drive when I’m extremely sleep deprived. I’m plainly too distract-able and thinking about too many things at once while driving. I think this adds another layer to the self-doubt. 

I’ve brought it up with my psych and we both really don’t know what to make of it. Just to trust my gut and not drive when it feels unsafe.

title: Focus on the journey, not the destination ❤️
content:
I am 36 years old. I was diagnosed when I was 22 but I’ve pretty much been dealing with this shit as long as I can remember. I’ve been on every med imaginable, been in the hospital 20+ times (I’ve honestly lost count), attempted 3 times. I’ve been in therapy since I was 12 (off and on but mostly on), I’ve been in groups, DBT, IOP, I’ve tried ECT. 🤦🏻‍♀️ I’ve done it all. And I’m exhausted. 

I probably contribute a lot to that exhaustion though because I fight this disease every step of the way. Most of the time I can’t even admit that I have bipolar. I can admit to some kind of chemical imbalance, but do I actually believe I have bipolar?? Sometimes yes and sometimes no. I have such a hard time with meds. I have a lot of paranoia and a lot of that paranoia has to do with taking meds. Not just bipolar meds but all meds. I have all these thoughts that invade my brain and I can’t shake them. 

I went off meds last September because of that paranoia. I think that people are trying to control me. That I’m not bipolar and because of that I don’t need meds and people telling me that I need them are trying to control my brian. Turning me into a mindless robot or trying to poison me. I just have a really hard time with them. 

But I went to see my psychiatrist today and got back on lithium because I seriously can’t take it anymore and recognized that I needed to do something. And everyone in my life is so happy about me being back on meds. But I’m still struggling. I hate this so much. I don’t want to deal with this anymore. It’s so painful. And I’m just exhausted. 

I just think of that scene in shameless where Ian goes to get meds and asks the psychiatrist how long he needs to take them for. And she basically tells him forever. It’s forever. I just can’t seem to accept it. I keep thinking that things will change or I’ll be different and I never am. I think it’s time for me to grow up and accept it. I’m just struggling. 

If you gotten this far into my rant I thank you. But I want to hear your story. What has your journey looked like? What has worked and what hasn’t? Has accepting this illness been difficult for you too? 

Bipolar is not for the weak. You have survived 100% of your hardest days. You will continue to survive and thrive. I am proud of you ❤️

title: Memory issues during episodes
content:
I have just recently begun to realize I'm probably in a manic or hypomanic episode. I'm still learning my own triggers and warning signs, so I didn't notice for at least a few weeks.

For example, all week I have been planning to see my therapist today (Friday). I remember checking my appointment card and seeing the date as 1/17. But this morning I decided to double check the time, and I noticed it said 1/24... something similar happened about a week ago where I remembered seeing the dollar amount in my account as 2 something. It makes me feel like I can't trust anything I think/know. Like I'm not in control anymore. The good news is I had felt myself getting off track, so I have been using notes, pictures, and  even my husband to help keep me on the right track.. it's just unsettling not knowing what's true right now. I am trying to stick with simple tasks I can't really mess up as well; if that makes sense.. 

I was just wondering if this is a common type of thing for people in episodes. I hadn't noticed this before, but I wasn't very self aware before my diagnosis either. Things I read online did say bipolar caused certain memory and cognitive problems.

title: Are you consciously aware that you’re making reckless decisions when manic?
content:

Does anyone else experience this? Or when you are hypomanic/manic, do you think “yeah this is fully the right decision” and only realize you were reckless when it passes?

title: So a funny thing just happened.
content:
I've just recently had to let the love of my life go for a little while. We both have things we need to do before we can be together again and I wanted to make him some breakfast for his last visit and let him know what was going on with me. 

I thought he was going to be here for two or three days, cuz he said he would be. I was getting better after I decided to quit my job and jump on some education. There was a possibility he could get me to my appointment for moral support. Everything's good. 

When he got here I was so excited to show him how much better I was feeling but I was still nervous about "the talk" so I wasn't as animated as I wanted to be. 

We did our dos and cuddled and he comforted me like he always does. I thought it was a little weird that he dismissed my small victories... and THEN...

Turns out he was thinking p much the same exact thing except he thought it was a good idea to basically yell at me for having my mental illness and struggling with it for so long (there were so many factors to this depressive episode. It's ridiculous. It should have only taken a few months.) 

I SHUT DOWN. There was NO way I was going to tell him how I felt about him then. I tried to stand up for myself a few times, but he'd just raise his voice and tell me another thing that I guess he hates about me.

Last thing I remember is me getting out of his car after he took me to the store to get some nicotine. 

He says "see you"

I thought about it. "Sure." And I closed the door.

I think I gave it, like... A day? Before I started with my arsenal of questioning that he had rightfully earned himself. 

And this man. I love this man. He is a CHAMPION and he answers my questions. He tells me he doesn't hate me when I ask. He listened to me cry about the way he treated me on the phone. He took SO MUCH questioning for, like, two weeks. He's the best, really. He's my best friend.

I recently concluded this MASSIVE storm of inquiry with a phone call. I think he understands now. And I hope he knows how much I really do think of him.

I just thought this was kinda funny but also, like. If it was three days sooner that would have been a straight shot to the psyche ward and I've been trying to avoid that since 2023 so...

And I have despite! Go me! 🥳 Things are turning up, I think.

title: Does anyone have any positive psych ward experiences?
content:
The psych ward can bring up horrible memories of psychosis, panic, and mistreatment. 

Ive also have some of my most cherished memories from the psych ward. 

I  bonded with a tech, he would guide me through each day, redirecting my confusion and gently going along with my psychosis to make me feel safe and understood. The best part was he would read to me each night as he knew I had trouble falling asleep. He gave me a pho hug (touching patents isn't allowed) when I left and complimented my character and told me how grateful he was for our friendship. 

At a different psych ward I had a group of friends all around the same age. We did our best to pass the time together. We made up games with the limited items they would give us and developed real camaraderie. One day my roommate who had been in a wheel chair got up and decided his injury was healed enough. I was in terrible spirits deep depression after coming down from mania. When I sat in that chair and all of my friends wheeled me around it was the happiest I had been in my life. It doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but just palling around with everyone that had fought together through mania or psychosis filled me up. 

  
If you have your own positive stories I would love to hear them!

title: Lost Cause?
content:
Lost cause?

Hi. I don’t normally post anything on Reddit but I’m feeling kind of helpless. I was diagnosed with Bipolar 2 when I was 17 and more recently have been diagnosed with PTSD as well as exploring a possible ADHD diagnosis.

I lost my grandfather (who I was extremely close to) in September 2023 and my uncle committed suicide in December 2023. I also had approximately 4-5 other significant life triggers within that time frame, which lead me to have the worst manic episode I’ve had since 2009. (In 2009, I mistakenly thought that I was depressed because I had a cutting problem that lead me to six 51/50s within that year… When I recently learned that those were actually manic episodes because I had extreme life triggers that no 17 year old should have had to experience.) 

The manic episode I had in December 2023 to January 2024 was so extreme that I physically felt the come down from it - everything slowed down and I was drinking up to 6 espresso shots daily to try to get my energy back because I didn’t understand what was going on. 

Approximately a year ago, the results of my manic episodes slapped me in the face and my life has felt like it’s going downhill ever since. I developed terrible panic attacks, constantly had to call out of work because of the depressive episodes. 

Although I was (and still am) very proud of myself for pushing through in my professional life when I’d normally abruptly quit in the past but I can’t help but wonder if that ended up hurting me in the end. My job let me go in August 2024 for supposedly “taking advantage of my accommodations” (which was false btw) and I’ve been in a massive depressive rut ever since. 

Normally when I’m unemployed (I have so many gaps in my resume because I can’t hold a job… I always quit) I develop some sort of routine to keep myself productive. This time around I’ve struggled daily. I cannot feel rested no matter how much I sleep. I have gained weight, which I already have body dysmorphia so that’s definitely not helping. (🙃) I’ve been applying to jobs left and right… Have only gotten rejection letters.  It’s not that I don’t want to be productive - I feel physically and mentally exhausted. 

I have a good medical team behind me - great psychiatrist and recently found a decent psychologist. But I feel as though I’m a lost cause because I haven’t felt like myself in over a year. 

Has anyone else experienced anything similar? I really just don’t know what else to do… I feel as though I keep trying to do everything I’m supposed to do in my treatment but it’s not working. I feel overall discouraged and that I’m helpless.

title: I really miss feeling understood
content: So far in my life the only person to really get me was my ex. I met him about 5 and a half years ago. I can’t believe it was that long ago. I can’t tell you how much I miss feeling seen or not having to explain. He just got me, I was 100% myself with him all the time. My family does not get me, they love me but man I feel misunderstood. For a long time I craved to feel wanted, now that I think that hole is a bit more filled I crave to feel understood. I hate feeling like an alien, I absolutely hate it.

title: Apathy, or a return to normal?
content: I recently started on a new antidepressant and am feeling less depressed but also not as joyful or excited as I feel like I used to. Was I just hypomanic? Is this what it's like to feel normal? How can you tell? Thanks.

title: Weightloss on meds?
content:
Hi all,

This is my 2nd ever reddit post so if I mess anything up please let me know so I know for the future. 

So for some background, I have been on meds for about 2 years now and have had no issues with the manufacturer of meds. Its been amazing for me and I live a relatively normal life (I know this is not always the case and I feel very fortunate to have been able to find something that works on the first try). More background on me as a person, I am relatively active and have an extensive background in health and wellness (this is not a post about advice on changes to that). For the last 10 years I maintained the same weight even after getting on meds. 

The issue arose when my pharmacy switched my manufacturer of my meds without informing me around 6 or 8 months ago. The meds werent working for my symptoms and I gained weight within a month. I promptly contacted the pharmacy to have them switch back to the other manufacturer and had no problems with my symptoms again after that. The issue is that the weight and food noise from being on the other meds has not gone away. I was on a common prescription weightloss drug for a month or two right after the med mixup which helped with the food noise but the weight didnt budge so I decided to get off of it. I am by no means at an unhealthy weight but I am VERY uncomfortable in the body I have now. 

So my main question for everyone here is has anyone had this problem and been able to get the food noise and weight off again? I am worried this will just be the rest of my life and its very hard for me dealing with the food noise. I do have some ed tendencies that I have "recovered" from mostly but this issue is flaring some of that up. I exercise and eat for health and know its not about the number on the scale. I just want to feel like my normal self before those meds messed me up. 

Additional info: I have a therapist and do work with her on these things too.

Thanks in advance!!

title: Personal questions
content: I’m wondering, how did you all tell people around you about your bipolar disorder? Did you at all? Who did you keep it *from*? I do not speak to my side of my family ina regular basis, and live with my husband and his relatives. I have type two & ADHD. The depressive episodes are getting worse. I’m adjusting to my new medications/insurance issues.

title: When should I share?
content:
I (18F) got diagnosed a few days before my 17th birthday. I've always been open about my mental health struggles, being in the system from about 12 helped with that ig. Being bipolar has so much stigma I don't share it as much. The people I have told either are incredibly uneducated and assume a lot of stuff, or have no idea what it even is. I'm fine with explaining, it's just the predjudice that hurts i guess. 

My dad got diagnosed in his late thirties, and my mum's always kinda held this hatred for bipolar since their divorce, stating it effects her more than it'll ever effect me sort of thing, which is a bit fucked. I can see where she's coming from, but some of the stuff she says is crazy outlandish and has just put a sour taste in my mouth when i think about dating and having relationships with bipolar.

I've been talking to this guy (m19/20?) for a few weeks now. He's geniune and kind and we have so many mutual interests, and better yet he's actually interested in me regardless of med weight gain! I'm meeting up with him in a few weeks. I'm well medicated, as stable as I possibly could be, have an amazing mental health team, the whole lot. But at the end of the day I'm bipolar and that's a heavy burden. Should I tell him soon? Is that a first date kinda thing? Rip the bandaid? I feel like I owe it to him.

title: Can’t take it anymore
content: I’ve been on meds for the past three days and it’s also the first week of my last sem in uni. I’m supposed to catch up and bring my gpa up but how am I supposed to do it? I feel apathetic because of the meds. I want to stop or lower the dose for a bit and maybe continue once I graduate, is that possible? I was fine before, it’s not like I was self-harming, I just have terrible focus and would stay up all night sometimes. I’m not even sure if what I said to the two psychiatrists I’ve been to are accurate what if I just felt pressured to say yes to their questions and I’m not really bipolar?

title: Do we just have to keep trying, forever?
content:
Man I'm so over trying. Trying to be stable, going to doctors, psychiatrists, therapy. Trying to lose weight that I put on from medication. Trying to be a better person, for seemingly forever. Trying to stay off marijuana. Trying to exercise. Trying new hobbies. 

It's always try, try be better. When does the cycle at least calm down?

title: How to handle when you get delusions about people?
content: Getting delusions about people is probably the thing that ruins my friendships the most. It’s awful and when I start using logic I begin to feel very bad. I also have OCD and I feel like my obsession in combination with delusion has been really harming my friendships. It’s not okay and I know that but I need to get better before things can resume or before I can text the people I care about. My delusions have harmed me and the people I care about immensely, and it’s not an excuse but I want to get better. It’s hard to use logic when the delusions get in the way. I feel like everybody can read my mind and tell how much of an awful person I am now that I’m beginning to come out of my latest delusion. I just wish there was a way for me to see logic and reasoning.

title: Experience asking your boss for ADA accommodation?
content:
Hi everyone, I’m wondering if anyone has experience working with their boss to make accommodations according to the Americans with Disabilities Act. 

I’ve been working at my current job for 6 months and I really like it, but I’m starting to get burnt out, mixed with seasonal depression, mixed with not being able to afford my ADHD meds anymore and losing focus and motivation. 

Today I absolutely can not bring myself to go to work. I haven’t showered in 5 days so I feel gross and bad, I haven’t meal prepped so I have nothing to eat for lunch, I’m behind on homework, I’m melancholy and tired and grumpy and I absolutely do not want to go in public at all or stare at a computer for 8 hours when I’m going through all of this. 

In the last 6 months this has happened to me about three times, which isn’t so bad, but I’m burning through all of my sick leave and will soon have to take vacation time to accommodate my mental health days. 

All I want as an ADA accommodation is maybe a few extra days of PTO a year to take mental health days. Because I often times force myself to go to work anyway when I feel like this which just makes the problem worse in the long run. 

Does anyone have experience where they have successfully worked something like this out with their employer? How did you bring it up to them? How raw and personal did you have to get in the discussion? Any advice or experience would be greatly appreciated!!

title: No support group other than y’all, starting to feel stable :)
content:
I wanted to share how grateful I am for this subreddit and how much it’s helped me. I would love to do group therapy but it’s not possible for me at the moment so this is the next best thing. I was so scared when I first got my diagnosis and y’all really helped me. I’ve been on my medication and therapy and it’s been building a routine and after two hospitalizations and nearly attempting suicide I finally feel excited for the future. 

I’m young (21) and having support from the older folk of the community has meant a lot since my parents don’t believe in my diagnosis. I’m excited for school to start and I feel like I can really succeed. With my new medication I feel a calmness and control I’ve never felt in my life. I can actually think straight! I’m not paranoid! I feel calm! I realized how okay I felt the other day and just cried to myself. I’m so grateful to my therapist, psychiatrist, the hospital staff, y’all, my friends and my family (they support me albeit fractured support). I’m scared of evil eye/jealousy but I wanted to share with someone after 7 years of struggling and wrong diagnosis I feel optimistic.

title: 1 date, 2 months in a psych ward. I still can't forgive myself.
content:
I met him around 10 months ago, we were made for each other. Same taste in music, same taste in games, similar age. I was in love.


Unfortunately we lived 5 hours away from each other, so we only met once, but it was the best weekend in my life.


I wasn't diagnosed back then, and I was really unstable. I was such a downer, I kept putting myself down and complaining, because I felt undeserving of his company. He had a degree and a good job, and I wasn't in college, and had never worked. I felt useless, and maybe I am.


It was too much for him. When I realized I fucked things up I had my first attempt. When I discovered he went back to his boyfriend I attempted again, this time I got sent to a psych ward, where I spent 2 months. 


My medication made me stable for the first time, but I think this stability has come to an end recently, and maybe it has something to do with him. I love him. I can't forget him. I can't forgive myself. I'm talking to another guy but still can't forget him.

title: I need hope, I cannot stand how I feel...
content: Suicidal ideation, feelings of impending doom, inability to concentrate. I'm talking 24/7/365. No rest from these feelings outside of sleep. I'm such a mess on my current medication. Did anyone ever feel like this and then it got better? Sorry to be such a downer...

title: My brief story / what can I expect on meds?
content:
I was hospitalized twice recently (both about a week) and would like to hear personal stories as I’m newly diagnosed here. I’m on my first week back out of the hospital. Maybe I’ll go into the details into another post. 29M. 

And it feels like I’m experiencing so much of the world for the first time - there’s a sense of calmness and stillness inside my brain that I haven’t felt in a while. There’s also a sense of serotonin (I think that’s what it is?) - like this feeling of being cared for. I appreciate it. That being said though I still feel like I’m figuring myself out, or figuring out who I am. What else can I expect on meds? 

I’ve always loved horror stories, Edgar Allan Poe etc. - they’re a wonderful expressive way of exploring darkness. Now it feels like I’ve been living my own especially given the stuff that landed me in the hospital. My own recovery journey, etc. it’s an analogue, not a literal interpretation. 

Are there any stories (horror or not) that you enjoy about bipolar or serve as an allegory?

I know I’m asking a lot but I’m so new to this, so I appreciate the help.

title: An existential void in my heart [TW:Past SI+actions, no SI rn]
content:
TW: Non-graphic discussion of past suicidal actions. Not currently suicidal.

\-------------------------------------------------

\-------------------------------------------------

Hi. I am bipolar type II and ADHD. A year ago, I attempted suicide and shortly after, developed PTSD. 

I’m working through that last one through EMDR, and my therapist is good. I’m gaining more clarity over time, and can actually think about what happened without reliving that moment.

Ironically, it is that clarity that I now find distressing. Because:

1. That attempt was not an isolated incident, but the result of a half-decade long spiral with increasingly dangerous suicidal behaviors.
2. Before, I thought that I very well could have died. I now know that it’s worse. My death was overwhelmingly the most likely outcome,  with sheer coincidence saving me. **Medically speaking, I should be dead**.

This is bringing forth a lot of existential feelings and questions. Sometimes the world feels surreal and I feel disconnected, as if I am far away. Sometimes I feel like I am a dead man walking, living on borrowed time. Sometimes, the death I narrowly missed feels more real than the life I have right now.

Reading this back, I think I must be insane. I don’t want to die, there’s too much remaining. I want to live. But sometimes it feels like my fate is already sealed.

title: Personality changes while stabilizing
content:
Has anyone else experienced this? i feelike before I was diagnosed and on meds I had such black and white thinking and extreme opinions/positions on things. Stupid stuff like I swore I hated cinnamon and bananas. i feel like I had an opinion about everything, not necessarily in an annoying way, but in a very self assured way. 

I'm realizing so much of my black and white thinking and general intensity was actually just symptoms of my bipolar? I've eaten like 4 bananas in 2 weeks and have been brewing my coffee with a little cinnamon recently. It's fucking weird. 

There's part of me that's scared to lose the things that made me uniquely me, and most of me that is feeling excited to see how I change and stabilize, and trying not to feel too sad about unstable parts of me fading away. 

What changes have you noticed? Any weird ones?

title: Irritation from sounds
content: Hello, everyone. I’ve been diagnosed and dealing with bipolar for years now. A couple of years ago I went through my first proper psychosis that took months to come down from and grasp real life again. Then I got the most terrible and intense depressive episode. I got out of it around two months ago and my life is so much better. I started a project on my own, i cleaned and organized my room, I’m dressing well again. The past few weeks I had difficulty sleeping and some auditory hallucinations and I visited the psychiatrist and got meds upgrade to match the episode. But the weird and new thing is how irritating sounds are. Loud sounds, ringing like bells and phones, tv and videos, people talking or shouting. I always liked the quiet and needed quiet sounds but not to this extent. I feel like clawing my brain if someone played an annoying video next me. I feel my blood boiling if the tv is loud and annoying. Anyone else experienced this? How do I keep it under control, because I’m living with family and it doesn’t make sense to ask the whole house to be quiet all the time so i’m triggered.

title: Need an outside point of view on my thoughts to know if it's hospital time
content:
So I thought I was just hypomanic since 5 days ago and I even assured my therapist today that I'll be fine. Now half of my brain is telling the other half that my goal in life is to be submerged in the world and if I die right now I'll get into a celestial world that's the final destination of my existence nad I should reach it right now. My other half responds: keep calm, this is mania, don't kill yourself.


Is this the peak of delusions and should I just go back home and lock the doors and sleep, or can it get more dangerous and I should get immediate help?

Hospital is almost not an option. What other thing can I do to stay safe? Do I even need to stay safe?

title: How should I celebrate a year of stability?
content:
After attempts, hospitalizations, police, etc., I finally found the right meds and therapy. It’s been a year and haven’t had any episodes - depressive or manic. I am starting to feel like my old normal self again, and my heart is full of hope for the future. 

I’d like to celebrate this in some way, but how should I? I can’t throw a party to announce this, it would expose too much about my mental health. I’m thinking of doing something nice for myself. 

Has anyone done anything to celebrate stability? I’m taking notes :)

title: I think I'm about to become a pool cleaner
content:
After nearly 20 years in IT, I'm burned out.  I haven't kept up to date with my skills I should have at this age.  I frankly just don't care about tech anymore like I used to.

Today is my last day at a job I got no more than 6 months ago.  I feel so stupid and ashamed.  My fiancee has enforced that jobs are just for paying bills, that she doesn't look at me any differently.  I consider myself lucky to have her.  

So now I'm on the search for a simple job.  Pool cleaner keeps coming up in my searches - I'm only high school educated.  I'm sad that I have to leave cozy office job for working outside.  I worry that I still won't be able to do the work of pool cleaner.  But I have to find something to pay the bills.

Has anyone made a similar move beforre?  Traded in a white collar job for a blue one?  

I could use some inspiration from others who found themselves in a similar boat.

title: So this is it ? Until the day I die ?
content:
EDIT: I removed the name of the medication as per the rules

I was recently diagnosed last year after some other disorders, substance abuse and wrong prescriptions caused consecutive false positives and negatives. One day my mom gave a fairly common antipsychotic for insomnia and I started taking it regularly just to sleep and I casually mentioned to my psychiatrist just as a heads ups and how it made me oddly stable. 

And that's when it clicked for him and after a few hours of going through my mental health records and asking questions it all started finally making some fucking sense for me after hearing the explanation.

What doesn't sit well with me is that this is it ? 
Therapy, adjusting mood stabilizers for the one that works best till the day I die and toughing it out the episodes ? What a sick fucking joke.

Sorry if all of this is recently diagnosed frustrations but now that I'm starting to pick up when I'm having certain symptoms and know what's coming next... it's almost like I'd rather be punched by surprise, knowing the punch is coming only makes it more frustrating and I'm not sure how all of you deal or dealt with this.

The only thing fair in life is how equally unfair it is isn't it.

title: TW: SH
content: I realized in three hours I’ll be fifty days free from self-harm!! At first I didn’t really care about it and was like “well who cares” then I realized I needed to have the mental strength to care about my own body & life even if I had negative feelings towards myself or if something happened that day. I’ve been through a lot these past few months including getting diagnosed with BD, and changing medications a bunch of times to the point where my meds are still being adjusted. 😭 I hope something starts working soon but this little victory felt like a sign that things are going to be okay.

title: Worried about how to live life
content: For the past 10 months after I got diagnosed I was fixated on what to do with my life. I finally figured it out, but I'm upset because I don't know if I can have a normal life. I am diagnosed with Autism and Bipolar. I sometimes have some sleeping issues and I think about how that could impact my job if I got one. Right now the sleeping issues are not too bad (I wake up at 6 AM and sort of stay up) but they can get bad. Sometimes the sleeping issues are hard, I get psychogenic itches and they keep me up at night, or I just don't feel tired and stay awake. This problem is leading me to having suicidal thoughts. Why live if I'm going to suffer trying to keep a job?

title: feels like i’m making it all up
content: do you guys ever want to reach out for help or talk about your experiences at a time when you’re doing okay, but you feel like you’re making all of it up and the dark times you went through are just stories you made up in your mind? it’s making it impossible to really open up about things. if so do you have any advice or suggestions?

title: Goal setting feels impossible
content:
Recently my friend asked what my goals were for the new year and I drew a complete blank. He went on to ask if I had a simple goal for the week and again nothing came to my mind. He could tell I was struggling and asked if there were any goals I had set just for the day and finally I answered "make it through hour by hour until the next day". 

I used to have grand goals in college before my diagnosis. Romantic, entrepreneurial, health, etc. Now I exist as I am struggling though day by day. 

Can anyone relate?

title: Keeping friends is difficult
content: Do you guys find that keeping friends is difficult? When manic, I will create a new life complete with a new bunch of friends because who can resist my gorgeous-manic self?!?!  Then I will explode the new life with wild changes and lose my friends. I have like no “old” friends. The road behind me is littered with casualties. Anyone else?

title: Is exercise really as helpful as people say?
content: I’m gonna be honest I’m really skeptical that exercising regularly helps with bipolar. My doctor, therapist and psych are all pushing me to do it but I find it very boring. I think if I hear it from y’all or see the statistics somewhere I’ll be more likely to do it. Also what exercise have you found to be helpful and what has not been helpful.

title: Reverted to a childlike/infantile state and find it hard to be confident.
content:
So during the major episode, I pretty much reverted to a childlike/infantile state where I needed help from my immediate loved ones or I was probably going to die. I remember being mute through a lot of it. I remember being absolutely terrified and thinking people outside were trying to kill me/us. Sometimes it felt like my body was moving on its own while I was an unwilling passenger. 

Needless to say, it was mortifying, and I've lost what little confidence I had. Prior to the episode, I remember having an inkling that maybe I was finally ready to try dating. Then the episode happened and I've pretty much sworn off the possibility. But even day to day interactions with people, and especially people of the opposite sex, I just feel like a helpless kid, and it's demoralizing. 

I felt like was finally figuring things out before my episode. I'm honestly terrified of life.

content: Does anyone else also experience this? I don’t know what to do besides getting back on the meds. I hate being so angry all the time. I don’t understand why this happens though. I’m so tired.

title: It only lasted three days
content: I had three good days. I got so much done I felt unstoppable. I was really paranoid and still am but even with the paranoia I felt kinda good. I don’t feel really happy or really depressed like I usually do. I feel kind of sad but not in a debilitating way. I’ve been having panic attacks for a few weeks mainly because of the paranoia. Does anyone have any advice for not recognizing your face in the mirror? Sometimes I just stare because I don’t recognize the person that’s looking at me. I don’t know how to put this feeling into words. The best way I could describe it is that I feel like my “happiness” is shutting down. Is there a name for this feeling?
