title: I’ve reached an all time low. My poor cat couldn’t even use her litter box.
content: For months I’ve been struggling to keep up with my cats litter box. Every time I say I’m going to clean it sooner, but never do. It goes days at a time right now, and before diagnosis I would keep up with it DAILY for YEARS. I feel so bad for her. She doesn’t deserve a dirty box. Anyways, tonight she has been acting really weird. I find her in my makeshift closet scratching around on my (I not even kid you) never before warn authentic Peyton Manning jersey from when I was a kid and he was on the Colts. I wouldn’t have been mad at her for using it as her bathroom though. I definitely deserve it. Anyways, so at this point I then knew it was her litter box. I go to clean it and it was the fullest it’s ever been. As soon as I started she immediately jumps in and pees in the one little spot I cleaned out. I was devastated. I wanted to cry. I dumped her box and gave her all fresh litter. She is so happy now. She knows I’m hurting. She tries her best to help. A lot is going on my life right now and my mental is relentless. Please refrain from saying mean things. I’m harder on myself than you could ever be. I was in the army to give you an idea. I promise I will do better guys. I just can’t believe I’m actually being swallowed by depression like this.

title: Working on reframing the different parts of myself
content: So instead of “reckless”, my manic part is “generous”, “brave”, and “ empathetic” and instead of “lazy”, my depressed part is “tired” and “contemplative”. That way, it helps with the unrelenting guilt and shame I feel after coming out of an episode. Has anyone else had luck with this?

title: Just need advice
content: So I was diagnosed with bipolar just a year ago and now my life has just felt like total numbness. I’ve been on two different medications but when I’m on my meds I feel nothing and when I’m off them, I feel a bit happier. But this last week I didn’t take my pills for 2 days, and left work because “I wasn’t feeling well”. I have no energy to do anything and it’s hard to sleep. I’ve only get 5 hours of sleep before I wake up for no reason. All my hobbies don’t give me any joy, time feels slow. I have some support like my wife but she’s had to deal with my ups and downs for a while now. I keep trying to sleep at normal times but anytime I do I wake up no matter what. I’ve taken pills to help me sleep but no matter what I do I feel tired and sore. I wanted to write this to clear my head and maybe someone has gone through this to help me in anyway, I just don’t want this disorder to affect my family. Any advice would be greatly appreciated

title: Got back on my medication
content: A little back story: I had been on medication for my bi polar diagnosis a couple years ago but had to stop taking it durning my first pregnancy. I couldn’t gain weight and my daughter was on the small side so my doctor and I thought it was for the best to stop medication until my daughter was born. Well here we are almost two years later and I’m pregnant again. But this pregnancy made me realize that I needed to get back on my medication. I started seeing a new doctor and she prescribed me a med that is safe for pregnancy. I have been on it two weeks and I can tell a huge difference. My motivation is back and not so depressed about everything! It’s amazing and I hope it continues to work for me 💜

title: I've noticed I cry a lot while manic
content: It's not in a depression way if that makes sense.. I just get a little emotional but not sad. Like I'll think about something and cry for a little bit then feel fine. I think it's because I also have a lot of trauma and mania makes me think deeper and faster. I just got done crying about the thought of my dad dying one day because he's an addict but now that I cried it out I feel fine and a little high. And earlier I cried about memories of an abusive relationship I was in even though that's been a couple years and I'm happy in my current relationship. I didn't feel the pitting depression like I do while in a depressed episode. It feels good in an odd way.. but I know I need to get ahold of it before it gets bad. I also feel paranoid about my current partner doing things that happened in my past relationship which Ive also noticed happens when I'm manic. Like I will literally feel like I'm being cheated on or something and have to find the evidence but can never find it and then when I'm no longer manic I realize that I was being irrational. Idk if that's a common part of mania for everyone or if it's just a combination of my ptsd diagnosis. I just wanted to share these thoughts to reflect on later.

title: Making sense of a manic episode that took my brain back like 8 years.
content:
I had a manic episode where I was getting flashbacks and tons of memories of an abusive ex from like 8 years prior. During this manic episode I was also in psychosis and thought I was connecting to the afterlife and I thought our relationship had significance in terms of our afterlife and ancestors? Idk it didn’t make sense, but during the episode I was also full of hurt and rage from the way he treated me. Ever since then I have been sedated as heck for like 4 years up until recently when I got a med change. With this med change my brain is working again and I’m even having dreams. Like I’ll think about him, but my dreams are just us where we’re talking. I also am like 90 days sober from weed (was addicted) so it could also be that I am adjusting to sobriety still or is it the med change? Idk I have a good life with an amazing husband, pets, life, career, goals so like things to look forward to. I guess I’m just trying to make sense of my brain and thoughts and stop looking in the past.

Tips? Suggestions? Anyone been in this situation before?

title: Do you guys ever feel ok?
content:

I’ve been happy and felt happiness but I felt like I havent had a peaceful and easy day for years. My quality of life is just not there. Can anyone relate to this? I’m feeling pretty down right now, which of course motivated me to reach out but I’m exhausted and I just wish that every day wasn’t a struggle. 

I have tried many things over the years, meditation, meds (which I’m currently on) many different kinds, therapy, exercise, etc. 
Can you guys relate? Has something helped for you that I’m missing? 


EDIT: 

Selfishly, it’s comforting knowing you guys can relate. We are strong. However, I’m so so sorry you guys can relate.

title: Depressed
content:
23F just feel like complete and utter sh*t. I have a good & flexible job with fantastic career prospects, which can sometimes be stressful but overall enjoy it. Have a nice bf who is supportive, we live together. I’ve lost a significant amount of weight in the last year/ year and a half ( i am 5’5, gone from BMI of around 31 to a BMI of ~22, not putting specific weights as I don’t want to trigger anyone). Wasn’t always overweight, only for about 3-4 years. Weirdly I’m way more self conscious now than I was before I lost it. Started the gym about 3 months ago and diet is generally healthy. 

Diagnosed type 2 bipolar disorder in summer 2022. My family live a few hours away, I love them but find it hard to be around them and where they live because of trauma and bad memories etc. 


I have a lot of friends who I mainly keep up with over messages because they’re either where I grew up or friends from uni who have since left our uni city. Can feel isolated because I don’t hang out with friends very often but then again sometimes the opportunity is there and I just don’t want to because I feel bad about myself/maybe a bit self conscious. I also struggle to relate to people my age perhaps because of trauma and having had a lot of life experiences that they haven’t. 

I’m in the UK so the winter darkness doesn’t help, I have a seasonal pattern with my moods.

On medication (mood stabiliser) no side effects. Under community mental health team but referral from them to psychology for therapy for my trauma/general issues was rejected because it might make me feel worse. I don’t contact CMHT because a doctor previously lied on all my notes to minimise my symptoms and issues with food, made a complaint which took months to get a response from (they messed it up) and just feel disheartened by the whole system. Doctor congratulates me on weight loss while I was crying about my relationship with food which is just so inappropriate and now I’m scared of the whole place even tho I won’t have to see that dr again. Can’t use normal NHS talking therapies due to my diagnosis they said my case is too complex. Had issues for years since approx age 12/13. I previously had private healthcare through my former employer and had private therapy which helped but I’m broke and can’t afford it now that I don’t have health insurance anymore. 

No idea where I’m going with this but yeah it’s just a rant, feel so let down by everything and the mental health care system I guess and idk where I’m going wrong because I’m trying so hard and still feel shit. Feel like they don’t take me seriously because I’m well put together and very self aware so I have a lot of insight into why I feel the way I do.

title: Partner Downplays my Hallucinations
content:
I have hallucination with my bipolar disorder. Both auditory and visual. I have been on a good medication regiment and I did major improvement several years ago with working out and therapy. Unfortunately my hallucinations have started back up again. My most common one is seeing flashes of light when there isn't one irl. I told my partner about these coming back and he completely dismissed me. He told me I'm always so negative and extreme, and jump to hallucinations as an "excuse". I feel as though I can no longer talk to him about them when they happen. It sucks because I usually use other people to gauge if it is real or not.

Any advice on how to proceed from here? I am planning on talking to my therapist about it tomorrow, but I would love to get some insights from this community.

title: Better mood, conflict ensues
content:
My doctor officially took me off one of my psych meds because I ran out of refills and, despite both the pharmacy and myself calling his office, he didn’t refill it for three weeks. We agreed to try going without it for four weeks because it’s the first time in months that I’ve felt like doing anything. I’m taking care of my fish, I’m eating breakfast outside, drinking more water, taking every excuse to leave the house. Unfortunately, not being depressed means I stand up for myself more in social situations, this includes with my mother. I came out six years ago this month, and she continues to misgender me and never apologizes. I called her out on it today, for the first time in months, and we ended up raising our voices with her saying she would never gender me correctly and I would quote “be mad about it until I die.” I corrected her that I would only be mad about it until she dies.
Should I get back on meds and go back into a depression for the sake of making nice with my mother? It’s literally the first time I’ve felt like life is worth living and she’s insisting I go back to not wanting to be alive. (For context, I’m 33, weeks are both disabled and on social security and live with my grandmother.)

title: Mantra
content:
So I always used to use the saying “I’ve got bigger fish to fry” whenever worried about a situation, then one day I started panicking and thought wow I have way too many fish to fry, I then thought why not just let the fish go, set them free, why worry over things you can’t change. 

I just thought I’d share this mantra, so next time you have too many fish to fry, maybe think about letting them go.

title: Hello people. I was diagnosed today and im scared.
content:
Sorry for my English and stuff but i don't have anyone to say all i want to say about it.

Today is the big day for me, it is good and bad like 50/50.

Around 3 years ago i was diagnosed with depression, for the first time i felt really good and wanted to live, like it was more on a mental side, just because i got a diagnosis of depression and could get medication, but after some time when euphoria left me and i had a big depression strike with suicidal thoughts for a few weeks until i found my soulmate and everything begun to feel good again so stopped taking the medication.

And then the war begun the depression came back but it was like for a 1-2 week at most with a moderate euphoria afterwards like one week on one side then one week on another side, didn't take it serius because of all situation in country and my family.

But for the last few months i felt really bad, I had and still have this idea in my head like "I never finish anything I start, so it's not even worth trying". So i decided to come back to my doctor (dude is on frontlines and still helps people) and he immediately diagnosed Bipolar Disorder 2nd group.

I'm scared because people in Ukraine don't want to understand people with mental disorders and are afraid of them, they think they are disabled, like people without arms and legs who need constant supervision and constant treatment in a mental hospital.

On the other hand, I'm glad that I finally know the exact diagnosis, that it is relatively mild, without strong manic episodes, although I'm afraid that I will never recover and become "normal." and will always have that stupid idea "I never finish anything I start, so it's not even worth trying" in my head, will never take my dreams seriously.

How do you live with it? Does it destroy your ambitions?

title: 20 yr old crisis
content: I have a big problem with trying to control peoples opinions on me. Instead of being myself and accepting who I am, I plant seeds of who I want to be into other people's minds. My life has become me psychoanalyzing everyone I meet. Every relationship I've been in whether it's been 1 month or 2 years has ended with the guy telling me I'm not emotionally available. This is true. I hide things and it's not for the purpose of being suspicious or hiding my secrets, it's for the purpose of preserving my self esteem. Once people know me , once they see me. They see me. I also think that being in a relationship with someone has much more of a likeliness of hurting them than it has of hurting me. For that reason only, it would be extremely selfish for me to get into a relationship with someone knowing I don't care as much as they do and I probably never will. I'm not evil and I have no intentions of hurting anyone. That's why I just watch from the sidelines. It's not nice to feel like you don't feel or you don't care anymore.

title: How do you handle decisions you made when you were manic?
content:
I made a lot of big decisions in my life while I was manic and having my mood plummet has left me with a lot of stress about handling my life now. I’ve started new relationships, ended others, quit my job, moved, made big purchases, etc. It lasted almost a year and when it ended, I was confused and afraid. My hair was so matted I had to cut it short and I’m mourning everything else I’ve lost. 

I’m stuck with a life I don’t recognize and now seems to make me unhappy. It genuinely feels like I don’t know these people and I’m stuck and regretful with everything that’s changed. 

I’m trying to convince myself that this thought process is just the result of a depressive episode and I don’t have to remove all these things but the voice in my head is saying that my life angers me because I’m looking at the consequences of my own decisions. 

I’m unable to recognize whether changes like breaking up with my boyfriend and dating someone else is just a result of being manic and I actually don’t love him now that I’m not obsessed with his existence. It happens in all my relationships where I’m told that I’m all of a sudden cold. Having people checking up on me feels like a burden. 

An absolute I made is that “I never break up with my boyfriend or make big decisions, but I’m also convinced I’m miserable.” 

I don’t know which things are true.

title: Why is the diagnosis so difficult to accept?
content:
I have experienced one long episode of mania.

I have been hospitalized for psychosis.

I have experienced one even longer episode of severe depression (and several milder episodes before this).

I have had multiple psychiatrists diagnose me with bipolar.

I take mood stabilizers that seem to work well.

I have no problem making the above statements. So why is it so difficult to say with conviction that I have bipolar disorder?

title: Thank God for Meds and Other Good News
content:
So I wanna make an update post. After starting my meds at the lowest dose I started integrating into therapeutic doses pretty quickly bc of my comorbidities (ptsd and mdd) but I'm so grateful for the changes I've seen in myself and how my life's been looking up.  A couple weeks after my psychiatrist diagnosed me, i decided to take a break from my boyfriend because my mental health was jeopardizing our relationship. I was making a lot of impulsive decisions that hurt him and ended up hurting me afterwards. 

Honestly considering how absolutely insane I've been for the past 2 months he's a saint lol. Not only did he inspire me to quit social media (i abuse the hell out of it), but he also put me in a position where I can just focus on school and my mental health and even through this recent break, he still supported me with all of that. 

Getting diagnosed helped me put it into perspective, but I realized it still didn't excuse the way I treated him towards during the weeks leading up to our break.  I also got into a huge fight with my family on Christmas that made me feel like I'd lost them forever but today makes a month since my life turned completely upside down and shit's finally starting to look up again.

For one, I got the apology I never thought I would receive. In my family it's very much "I mean what I said when I said it, but I'm sorry for the impact." We don't normally apologize for things we said in the heat of the moment, but we do forgive each other for how we felt. This apology was totally different. Tbh I burst into tears which shocked me because lately I feel like I can't cry. 

Last weekend my boyfriend came over to check on me and figure out what we're doing since we haven't really talked since New Years. I told him how sorry I was for hurting him while I was at my lowest & how much better I've been feeling lately. We ended up getting back together & nothing's really changed about us except it feels easy, like no one's waiting for the other shoe to drop.

 I get that it's only been a little over a month since I started taking meds but I really do think that aside from the headaches my life's improved in every area. I can feel things but they're not consuming. I don't feel the need to punish myself by thinking the worst-case scenario all the time about everything and everyone. 

I feel like I can start a craft/project/assignment and actually see it through till the end because I stopped using social media for the most part. And most of all my support system is fucking amazing right now. my family, my best friend, and my boyfriend are all back in my life & I'm almost done with my transfer degree.

I feel so much closer to living a stable life, with the career of my dreams and my loved ones by my side.

I know this is a long ass post but for anyone reading it I just thought I'd share some good news!

title: Has anyone gone off their meds(doc approved). And gotten IBS from nerves?

title: destructive internal voice
content:
Today I went on a coffee date with the friend I made in outpatient treatment.  She has schizoaffective, I have BP with psychotic features.  

At some point we talked about the internal voices we "hear" that go on and on and cause problems for us because of how intrusive they are.  Hers is expressed differently from mine (not sure if she'd be fine with me sharing so I won't) but mine is like this voice telling me how terrible and bad I am at everything, or how horrible everyone else or the world is.  It's relentless once it starts going and can endure for weeks or months.  

I said something about how I never knew that this was abnormal, the internal voice that is.  I thought everyone had this kind of voice running in their heads, just maybe not so negative as mine.  She'd had a similar realization not so long before as well. Both of us have had significant relief from these voices due to medication. 

I guess I'm sharing this because while I feel horrendously abnormal for this discovery, it was a huge comfort to have that discussion with her, to have someone else understand exactly what I was talking about.  Maybe someone else can find comfort in it too

title: Might get a divorce because of my actions…

title: Medication and therapy made a huge difference for me.
content:
I experienced a perfect storm several years ago. Murder, PTSD, unwise choice of friends, nasty break ups, struggles with autism and, icing on the cake of course- the onset of Bipolar. It ended my college education, career ambitions and friend circles in less than a year.  I didn’t think it was possible to feel that level of pain from loss.

My parents helped me recover for five years. Eventually I was compelled, angrily, to get therapy. With enough sessions it became clear that chemical intervention was necessary, and after getting genetic testing I was safely placed on a prescription on a low dose. It helps me sleep and acts as a mood stabilizer. It was not a cure-all. It meant making choices without bipolar’s insane drive. It's difficult to work with, but I’m also at peace. I can handle more work. I even found it in me to foster a loving friendship over the past three years. That friendship has been everything to me.

Not a perfect friendship mind you. Like today my friend wanted me to call her after I got home and I completely forgot. It made her feel like she's not a priority to me. Which couldn’t be further from the truth. In the past I would have ruminating pointlessly over the mistake, but now I find it in me to do a little better about being attentive to those things, though my progress is frustratingly slow. Getting a little better for our connection is one of the best rewards in the world and outside of those mistakes things have been wonderful.

Therapy and the extremely careful administration of drugs led me from a roller-coaster ride obsessive life to the richness of real friendship. Oh and the EMDR works now. It’s extremely effective at helping me work through powerful emotion and difficult memories.

If you’re on the fence about medication and therapy, don’t be. Find a good therapist and psychiatrist. Your life will change for the better.

I hope you find your needs met this year, and good friends to boot. :)

Much love,

Dim Giant

title: cptsd symptoms ALWAYS stay with my depression
content:
I have bipolar 1(with depression being my biggest problem) and CPTSD. I was actually depressed for the entirety of my life up to age 19, all throughout my trauma, and I never got any relief until I was put on meds that actually worked. 

These meds work WONDERS, but something about it confuses me. Pretty much as soon as my bipolar depression stabilized, so did my CPTSD. Without any trauma therapy or trauma processing, most of my CPTSD symptoms just went away on these meds. And I've noticed that when I have breakthrough depressive symptoms, some of my CPTSD symptoms return. 

I also noticed that since starting these meds my memory has gotten significantly worse, to the point where I have extreme difficulty voluntarily retreaving memories, including that of my trauma. and when something does force me to remember, there's no solid memory there, only flashes of images, very hard to put together coherently. 

I'm wondering if anyone else who also struggles with CPTSD has had similar experiences when finding emotional stability with meds?

The problem is, this fucking disorder, despite loving this job as a result of my treatment resistant bipolar, I have had to go to hospital a total of 15 times in the time I have worked here. Each time lasting atleast 2 weeks and as long as 5 months.  Needless to say i have not been the most reliable and consistent employee in my workplace. 

So far my manager has been understanding, holding my position so that aftery inevitable discharge i can return to work and proceed as normal (though recent admissions involving ECT has made that process a bit harder due to memory issues) and apart from the standard workmates questioning where I have never had any issues.

However I have noticed overtime as I go through more and more admissions, my manager has been getting more and more inpatient and unforgiving regarding my absences and I can't help but feel that it's gotten to the point where she is only keeping me on out of obligation and not desire. 

It has gotten to the point where despite me loving the job, I can't help but feel like I have overstayed my welcome and that it's better to just resign and live off disability benefits where I won't be a burden on any employer and giving me the time to find a way to achieve stability. 

So yeah, should I resign. Leave the job i love on a high note or stay in the same job out of my employers legal obligation. I genuinely don't know.

title: Cheerful mood mistaken for mania, hurt over it
content:
It’s been a really long time since I came here for support, but my weekly group just met yesterday so it’s going to be a while before I get a chance to talk to anyone about this. 

I saw a friend today after not seeing them since May. They are pretty much housebound with a physical ailment and they also have bipolar and other mental health issues just for context.

I have been doing well and stable for a while now. I haven’t been hospitalized since 2020 and I have been maintaining. It’s basically a full time job managing my bipolar and taking care of myself, but I’ve finally got a handle on things and it’s going well. 

So anyway, I go to visit my friend today and I am excited and cheerful. I’m pretty self aware and I definitely wasn’t really extra or anything. Just normal human emotions. 

I do need to consider the source because he is someone that is very fixated and sees everything through the lens of bipolar, but he made a comment that I seemed manic. I explained that no, I have a lot of routines and things in place where I definitely knew I was ok, just excited. He seemed to accept that but I just can’t stop feeling sad and hurt over it. 

I do so much work. I know I was fine. But I hate that I’m not allowed to just behave like a normal human being with normal human emotions without having it labeled as my bipolar. It’s not my fault I only see him every six months so it’s always like an occasion when I finally do see him in person. 

Anyway, I had to come vent somewhere. The “real me” is a cheerful and passionate person. I am not sure how I am supposed to act to have my behavior not considered manic. I wasn’t over the top. Do I have to dumb myself down to appear ‘normal’? I just want to stop feeling hurt over it.

title: It seems it was Ultradian Cycling all along
content:
I always question my bipolar diagnosis. But for the past 2-3 years I began to deny it.

However, yesterday my mood was very unstable. I noticed this week I have been feeling more unstable again. But the thing is I experience mood swings throughout the day pretty much everyday since 2020. (and honestly even before?)

Since my mid to late teens.

I started medication in 2020. I thought I just had treatment-resistant depression instead (I thought this by 2021/2022) but now it sounds I just have treatment-resistant bipolar.

Boredom is probably my biggest trigger for my depressed mood swings. With depression, I experience a great deal of anhedonia. I find it hard to focus and enjoy things. I don't have many hobbies. I feel too disabled to do college full-time or work even if it was part-time. I finally gotten around to apply for disability actually. I should've done it ages ago.

I'm sorry if this sounds tactful but I become unstable and go crazy when I have too much free time. It's why I do poorly during winter break and **especially** during summer break. 

I should mention I have sleep apnea and insomnia. Leaving sleep apnea unchecked for 3+ years seems to be the reason why my depression and focus issues never really improved after all this time. I did get a CPAP machine but I'm waiting to get a new mask before I'm actually able to fall and stay asleep with the machine.

I haven't been sleeping well this winter season. I experience daytime fatigueness and my symptoms have been getting worse since late 2024. I guess my worsening sleep quality probably explains why my mood, again, is becoming more unstable. I'm breaking down again.

I got diagnosed in 2020 after going to the ER three times. I stayed in the psych ward twice in 2020. Long story short I was experiencing>!suicidal mood swings. (passively?) Worried I would hurt myself or do something that might get me killed. I was worried about losing my mind. !<

title: everyone's an opp!!! (getting over paranoia)
content:
I deal with a lot of paranoia and I'd love to hear what's helped people get over it.

It started/got a lot worse in my (hypo?) manic episode (2 years ago), when I perceived most people, including my friends, as trying to "take me down," as if they didn't want the best for me because they wanted to ruin this high. I understand that's not the case but some part of me never recovered from that feeling that the world doesn't want me to be what feels good, especially since the thing that came of it was more traumatizing mental health "care."

I'm lucky to have gotten access to mental health care, I know its a privilege in a way to have that forced on me, but in most cases it's been traumatizing--threats, calling cops, and later a psych ward experience that genuinely traumatized me. it's hard to not feel confrontational with the world.

sometimes I think the paranoia is also an element of low-level psychotic symptoms, when it gets to a certain degree of sweepingness (or very occasionally thinking that inanimate objects are out to get me too).

this is coupled with a life history without long term people I "trust." I dont feel I can be honest with most people, and I automatically expect the worst from people, write them off, assume no one wants the best for me. like there's actually maybeeee 1 person in my life who I feel like knows me and wants the best for me (notably not my close friends, family, (ex-)partner or anything).

obviously this is causing issues, alienating me from community, and preventing me from seeing relationships past a certain degree of seriousness since the trust just doesn't develop--the relations sour with me unconvinced they care about me genuinely or even want the best for me, and I end it. 

I used to think this foundation of paranoia was okay, and even justified it with an elaborate worldview built on government surveillance, data control, etc. but I realized I was enabling myself, and I really do want the constant "on edge" feeling to go away.

does anyone relate?

title: Manic Exhaustion
content:
Any one else get that manic exhaustion?

Like you’re sleeping well. Maybe 6-8 hours

And you through the day just feel so exhausted. Maybe a little dizzy. Maybe a little sore. Like it hurts to move your arms you’re so tired.

But. Your body just wants do go. Your brain isn’t moving fast. But yet you feel like you wanna run and scream and play.

Like an engine reving on empty. Wheels spinning and not being able to actually go anywhere as the fuel is gone.

Like you’re super wired but also super tired?

Like your heart is pounding and your adrenaline is definitely pumping. You feel super motivated

But you’re just so tired. 

Maybe your mind is racing. But it’s also super light like you feel dizzy.

Your body is protesting with fatigue, but you just wanna “go.”

Like you’re about to fall asleep driving and yet you’re going 80 in a 30 with the music pounding beyond full volume.

Like you wanna collapse but can’t stop moving.

You just feel super chaotic and yet super weak.

Anyone get that feeling? 

Anyone?

title: Going back to work after two years - terrified and feel like a failure
content:
Hi. I'm 33, almost 34f, and have been living with my parents all my life due to not being able to support myself. I've had several jobs in the past, and all my money went poof with manic spending and actual expenses each time.

I was let go from a job two years ago, and it was 100% due to mania keeping me from keeping on task. It's the first time I've ever been let go before and it was very damaging. I had a major psychological setback, and then another after a family member passed, and another when my dog of ten years which I loved so much and staked so much of my mental wellness on died on the f\*cking US election night, of all nights. A date I'll never be able to forget for all the wrong reasons.

While I deeply appreciate my parents supporting me these past two years, I feel ungrateful and spoiled.

  
Flashforward to now, and I manically applied for over 100 job apps over the course of about five days (yes I'm medicated but only recently on a full dose of my first mood stabilizer.) I feel stupid for making more stress for myself, because now I have to field all these interview requests for places that I don't even really want to look for, but at the same time I can't be too choosy, I need to start somewhere right away. My parents are only getting older, they can't keep supporting me. And, oh yeah, I can't drive. Terrified of it. Mom's been driving me everywhere since as long as I've been alive and that also makes me feel like total scum, absolutely a total wastrel.

  
I hate feeling this way, because on one hand I know it's normal to feel this way, to be scared to enter the job field after so long, but I feel disgusted with myself for letting it go on for so long. Like a spoiled brat who's just stamping their foot and saying "But I don't wannaaaaaa"

  
I can't help but feeling like I've sabotaged my life and have to start back from basically ground zero because I lost all my momentum. I'm too fragile for this world but not willing to leave it.

title: How do you deal with a depressive episode?
content:
I was hypomanic for around eight years. In 2023 I was full blown manic. And now I have been in a depressive episode. 

It was pretty severe last fall. I was put on an antidepressant which helped me have the energy to workout. I began running again and it pulled me out of the depressive episode. 

Now the depressive episode is returning. I wake up at 4 AM and run five or more miles six days a week. This gives me a lot of relief. Then around 11 - 1 I start going into a depressive episode again. 

I was hypomanic for so long I understand this could easily go on for 2 - 5 years. I had to go to class today and I ran another mile with my dog. I'm about to go to the pool and swim a mile. I cycle 3 or so times a week and I lift two times a week. This amount of exercise may seem excessive. I wouldn't do quite as much but it literally allows me to be able to go to class or complete work assignments.

I'm simply looking for advice to treat this depressive episode. And also any feedback on how long it can last.

title: First Manic Episode
content: I am 20F and had my first manic episode at the end of November into early December. title: I think my meds have been ruining my life.
content:
Reposting with edits as I had misunderstood the rule about naming meds. Just wanna vent about this as it only just hit me.

TL;DR: I just realized my meds are probably the reason I've spent the past year feeling like shit.

I'm pretty bad at noticing patterns in my symptoms and keeping track of when something started or worsened, so I guess things crept up on me and I only noticed the correlation today. For months and months I've been complaining about extreme, constant fatigue, finding it almost impossible to get out of bed in the morning, and having so little energy that I can't complete the most basic tasks to take care of myself. I guess at first it just felt like depression, but it just kept going, even when I wasn't feeling depressed on an emotional level. I barely made any art throughout 2024, when before that I would make several pieces a month.

I've just been feeling so exhausted, so empty, and constantly waiting for an upswing that just *wouldn't come*. I got checked for sleep apnea and looked into chronic fatigue syndrome trying to figure out why everything was so hard and never let up.

Today something finally clicked and I started going through my journals, my now-abandoned day planners, conversations with friends, and realized this has been going on since early 2024 - when I started new mood stabilizers.

Now that I've noticed it it seems really obvious. I'm pretty frustrated with myself for not piecing it together until now. It's not even like I was clinging to it for any actual benefits - I've been telling my psychiatrist I don't think it's really helping the whole time, but I guess I thought maybe it had some slight beneficial effect so I should keep taking it.

So, yeah. I think I spent most of 2024 in a numb, exhausted rut because I didn't figure this out.

title: Ruined my life vent
content:
I wasn't on meds and was stable enough with mild depression for over a year and a half. In Nov 23 I had a decent paying job, my own apartment, car, and some social/dating life.

 In Dec 23 I went into a manic psychosis in which I lost all of that and became homeless and over the course of the next eight months had four inpatient hospital stays and eventually got arrested for stealing a car. I was charged in two states and am currently out on probation in one in a Christian sober residence (I'm atheist) and doing an intensive outpatient drug program everyday as part of my probation for weed addiction of all things. 

I still have a pending felony charge in the other state and am waiting for my probation to transfer so I can go live with my dad (at age 30) and have some support in that state. I might have to serve more time eventually.

 I'm back on meds now and don't know how much they can really help my depression from what I've gone through over the past year. Since I got out of jail almost four months ago life has been hell. I haven't had a job since Dec 23 and have nothing to my name and feel like the ultimate failure in life.

 I'm worried as hell my dad, who is the only person I even talk to anymore, is going to die soon (age 69) before I can even rebuild my life.

title: Bipolar 1 with no symptoms
content:
Hello all! I was diagnosed with bipolar 1 last year after experiencing my first manic episode and subsequent hypomania which ultimately ended up with me going to the hospital because I was not sleeping. Plus, my behavior was just generally erratic as some of us may be all too familiar with. Following the manic episode was the medication journey from hell. I won’t give names as per the subreddit rules, but my meds brought stability as well as a complete apathy for life in general. I was dealing with akathisia which made working very difficult as well as trying to enjoy my time in general. 

I finally switched to the last med that worked best for me where I started experiencing some normal moods again and feeling like myself for the first time in 9 months. It also feels worth mentioning to me that I was being medicated for anxiety in various ways for years before my manic episode. I had not been completely free of medication for years, and it made me realize that I had no idea what it could feel like to live off of meds. 

So, with the help of my psychiatrist and therapist, I safely stopped taking medication on December 31st, 2024. It is now 2 weeks in and I feel so much better. It has been a relief to experience my own personality again and just living life in a way that feels natural to me. I recognize how much of a risk it is to take by going on this path, and that’s why I’m making this post. It is my understanding from research that someone with bipolar 1 can live up to years without episodes occurring, not knowing when they will strike again. That’s what really scares me. I recognize that, chemically, this stability I have is probably temporary and there is no way to know when an episode will strike again.

I’m just so new to living with this disorder and it scares me. I want to hear from you all what your experience has been and if any of what I have said resonates. I look forward to hearing from you!

title: Safe and Sound Protocol with Bipolar 1?
content:
Hi Reddit,

My therapist suggested the safe and sound protocol last session.  It's described as music filtered to the frequencies of the human voice only to calm the nerve system.  For me it would be specific to my anxiety and overwhelm.  I'm currently in the depression phase of bipolar 1.  I know it is used for children with autism, for example, but that would not be my use case.

Here's the catch, it's through Unyte and my therapist wanted to charge $500 for access to the app.  I'm really skeptical that this filtered music is worth $500 and $500 seems like a lot of money to try a therapeutic method.  What if it does nothing?  Could i just find calm music to relax to that isn't $500?  I've combed the internet looking for a sample to test to see if it's remotely worth the money.  Unyte has their music held down pretty tightly, which is unfortunate in the sense that I'm likely go back to therapy saying that I don't have the money to try.  Still, I have some questions that feel unresolved.

Also, I cannot find anything to indicate that this method has been tested with individuals with Bipolar 1.  Could it cause me to swing back to a manic state?

Here are my questions:
1) Has anyone tried this method and felt like it was a success?

2) If it was a success, did you feel like it was directly due to the company's music?

3) How much of the success was learning how to sit quietly with one's thoughts and feelings and process them and the music was calming to help you do the bigger heavy lifting of learning how to relax?

3.5) Could calm music or podcasts (in the frequencies of human speech) be a suitable replacement?  Maybe put a filter on your phone?

4) Is anyone else skeptical of a filtered music app that costs so much and is this tightly gatekept?

5) Has anyone declined when this was suggested and had success with other therapeutic methods that also involved sitting still for much less money?

6) If there is a way to try before spending hundreds of dollars?

Discuss 😀

I’ve recently turned down a few guys who have genuinely been such kind, gentle, understanding (basically the whole package) dudes because i simply got bored of the attention or just wasn’t able to feel what i know i am supposed to. Yes, im aware that college is all about trial and error when it comes to dating and i’m aware that im most likely not going to meet my husband my freshman year lol, but this feels like a much deeper and much more terrifying experience than “just not being into them”. does anyone have any experience/advice? or can anyone else relate?

title: The guilt is heavy
content:
On paper, my life (besides bipolar disorder) is really great and I recognize daily just how privileged I am. 

I'm realizing I am now depressed again after two months of hypomania and feel extremely guilty for the way I feel. I know how I feel is valid because this mental illness is a mood disorder ie I cant really control how I feel, but man do I feel shame. 

It's hard for me to go through my depressive episodes without support but more than ever I feel extremely guilty for hating myself and my life and wishing it away. I get in the headspace that I shouldn't share a lick of what Im going through because it's insensitive to people with "real problems," which is something I would never ever say or think about someone else who struggles with mental health and do not believe. 

So obviously I know its the disorder talking when I have this guilt contrary to what I know and believe but I feel like such a pathetic loser for feeling depressed when most people could say that everything in life is going well for me in comparison. I guess that stands to validate mental illness because I am super aware and grateful for my blessings but when depressed, every waking moment feels like hell on earth and pure suffering. 

Hopefully others going through this can share the sentiment, and know that whatever you're going through, you're not alone in it. This sub has been super helpful to me in knowing I'm not the only one fighting a mental war daily.

title: How do you tell what is and isn't psychosis?
content:
I've had quite a few delusions and hallucinations during both depressions and hypomanias however I was told by my psychiatrist that in my case they cannot be part of psychosis, without giving explaining this much further, so at what point do you usually know that it's psychosis?

For hallucinations I'd usually smell things like chemicals, foods or unexplainable smells out of nowhere as if it where right in front of me, I hear voices but they usually don't speak to me and instead speak to themselves repeatedly or they just repeat some phrase over and over, sometimes they are the voices of my friends while alone at hone, othertimes its a very general voice and sometimes its just whispers, I've heard other things asides from voices like the door opening and closing, foot steps, my alarm ringing, in the case of voices I usually know they are just hallucinations and can ignore them, but when they are other noises, I cannot tell whether they are real or just hallucinations leading me to believe mh alarm was ringing, someone came into the house or that certain true sounds where just in my head when they weren't. These sound would usually appear for a afew seconds or minutes and disappear (in the case of the alarm, every time I looked at my phone it stopped ringing but it would start ringing again after a second or two, all for a minute or 2)

I'd also get some visual hallucinations like seeing people walk past in the house when empty, or vividly staring at a spider crawling up my arm and then after a few seconds swing it slowly disappear in front of me, I've also seen tall human like shadows around, and demonic figures in dark corners. I saw colours that werent there moving around like green pink and yellow beutifult colours moving around and swirling when looking at white walls, objects appeared to breathe, words moved slightly around, everything was so vivid and colorful. I'd also get this weird thing where I felt as if I were in two different situations at once, like being simultaneously lying in bed working with my laptop and being simultaneously there surrounded by the police and mg psychiatrist staring at me. 

As for delusions, I've believed j was a messiah and my friends had been chosen by God t show me the path to Islam, I believed I needed t convert and follow the path to defeating the antichrist which was going to arise any moment, it gave me some weird goose bumps, the end of the world was approaching and I had to fight evil. I've believed every add was trying to show me a secrete message for a government project, they knew id find out, i felt spied on. I've felt as if I could solve everything. Everything was connected and made sense, j was sure I was some super human and that everyone else was stupid. These delusions usually slowly popped in from the beginning of an episode, usually hypomania, but only fully became a delusions half way through the episodes.

I also would get this weird thing where nothing felt real and for a minute or so I couldn't understand English, it sounded different. The idea of being in school snd teaching felt weird and stupid so much it made me laugh. My friends felt slightly different, everything was alien like.

What makes this different from psychosis?

title: Is this normal?

title: Doing well
content:
Hello all,
I have been stable for over three years now after spending time in hospital and getting a medication change after a manic episode. I spent the months after my episode living with my parents. I finally got a decent job teaching and moved to a nearby city. Since my episode I have moved into a new home with my partner, gotten a dog, and started a new job working in the government as an environmental consultant. Sticking to a routine, exercising, regular therapy, and taking my medications consistently made a world of difference for me. If you had told me where I would be now shortly after my episode I would be in awe. Just wanted to share to show that things do get better and healing is a process!

title: Finally stable
content:
I was diagnosed with bipolar I five years ago, I was 25, I had my first depression at 11 and between those two dates I oscillated between denial, more or less severe depression and hypo-manic states until at the end of university when I experienced a fairly serious manic episode that no longer allowed anyone to doubt the fact that I really did have a problem and that it needed to be solved.   
  
I was lucky enough to quickly come across an exceptional doctor who allowed me to find my balance without taking a long-term treatment but only taking medication once the phases started. I know that it is not conventional and that it probably does not suit many people, but it is the choice we made and it ultimately worked for me. But it didn't work out perfectly right away and in the last 5 years everything hasn't been easy, I changed jobs 6 times, always jumping from one field to another, without consistency nor stability. I also moved 4 times. But in the last three years I really managed to stabilize myself. Two years ago I met a man with whom it was love at first sight and I got pregnant quickly, we got married. My pregnancy wasn't always easy but today I am a happily married and I love being a mother more than anything.   
  
As for my professional lifeI kept my last job for 3 years but it was the black spot of my life (very stressful, demanding and making me unstable), I finally quit it for a position as philosophy teacher in high school, I only teach 4 hours and I take care of my daughter the rest of the time. I don't make a lot of money (I used to) but I don't care because it's making me so much more relax, it's worth it.   
  
I am also being followed by a new doctor who understands my choice and whom I see once a month, just to make sure that everything is under control. Now that I am a mother, I am really afraid of experiencing new episodes that would negatively impact my daughter's life, but tonight I think about all the chaotic situations that I have experienced and I needed to share the satisfaction of finally knowing a long period of calm.

title: Do you get a little unstable when you first start taking medication?
content:
Hi all. I've been taking my medication since August 2024. At first, I felt like the medication was making me a bit unstable. Some days I'd be super productive, chatty, and would laugh a lot, while some days I'd be a bit sad, slow, and unmotivated. Then after maybe two months of taking my medication and never skipping a dose, I felt like I was finally becoming stable. Even then though, I'd have days that made it seem like I was going into depression, then some where it feels like I was going hypomanic. 



Due to circumstances wherein I could not take my medication, I would skip doses but only one day at a time. Since December 2024, I've started taking my medication religiously again and have promised to myself to never skip a dose again. I've noticed that I have recently only started to become stable again. Everything's alright, but I guess I just want to know if it's normal for medication to make you unstable when you first start taking it? Like some days feel like I'm going hypomanic, then on some it feels like I'm entering a depression. I'd ask my doctor, but they're away and my appointment is not for another month. I just want to know since if this is not normal, I might talk to my doc about medication adjustments. I also want to know since all of this is making me doubt if I'm even bipolar in the first place.

title: Some good news to share
content:
Hi all, its been just under a year sense I was diagnosed and 9 that I have been experiancing bipolor symptoms. 

I wanted to share the good news that I just experianced a hypomania and for the first time in years did not experience any hallucinations! I used to always see these star like dots of light that would twist and swirls around me like fireflys. On and off I belived they were protecting me from parinoia. 2 years ago these visuals progressed to patters on walls moving, solid serfaces breathing and belifs like these were teleportation holes opening. I was lucky to have a good friend who I could talk to and they would delecatly tell me what was real and what was not. 

I guess after 8 months my meds are at the right dose, and tho I deffinitly miss some of the extravagant feelings that came with hypomania, the fact that I skipped a depressive episode (which is equally as exciting! They were debilitating and sometimes down right scary) makes it worth it. 

So to everyone doubting the advice of experts, or frustrated with how long it takes to figure out what works for you. It works, and youll get there.

title: Sleep Talking
content:

Recently I did a staycation with my best friend of 20 years. She’s a night owl but after I take my sleepy time meds, I’m out cold. Apparently she had an entire conversation with me while I was asleep. Lol.

I’ve been staying at my great aunt‘s place lately. I crashed on the couch last night with a headache and had a horribly stressful dream. I was laughing, crying, moaning, and even shouting. Sometimes I wake myself up. I’m so loud.

title: My voices are weird
content:
I have schizoaffective disorder, and part of my hallucinations is hearing voices.

I hear them internally, as if they're thoughts, but different. I can tell the difference between my own regular thoughts and the voices. I don't always constantly hear them too. Sometimes is really nice talking to them, love feeling like they're friends that I don't have to watch what I say with. But other times all of them are all talking incoherently at once extremely loudly, all overlapping overwhelmingly and it makes me start spiraling most times.

I can only tell the difference between a few of them, both bc of their distinct accents. One is British, has the same wild humor that I do, very distinct accent. He's my favorite, we get along really well, though sadly I don't hear him much anymore. The other is also British, has the same type of British accent every time, and always has the same personality/thoughts (ones that are honestly insufferable at times). He refuses to want a name though, even though I really want something to address him by since I can always recognize him (the only one that passes is "the British one" 😭)

I can't tell the difference at all between all the other random ones though. Honestly I sometimes miss them when I haven't heard them in a while.

Random ass post, but I felt like talking about it 😅

title: Some things that helped me in my recovery from BP 1 w psychosis
content:
1. Getting the best doctor I possibly could, but not just by word of mouth but by verifying the reviews online which revealed more of the whole story about each doctor. 

2. Proper medication and dosage not being overmedicated nor undermedicated and being flexible with what that may mean in conjunction with my doctor.

3. Exercise - weight lifting, walks, Tai Chi, Yoga, Meditation (enormously helpful).

4. A clean wholesome and nutritious diet.

5. Getting a good night sleep every night and if I had a sleep disruption, in conjunction with my doctor using proper medication and/or herbals under my doctor's aegis to sleep well.

6. Breathing techniques that are calming. Dr. Andrew Weil recommends the 4-7-8 breath that he has on his website for calming over a 2-month period. And also "SKY" breathing has helped me heal a bit too --- it's not a panacea but it's helpful. 

7. Moderation and no toxins. I avoid alcohol, and don't do any drugs. I also don't drink caffeine. I was told by a top psychopharmacologist that many people can avoid a lot of manic episodes by avoiding caffeine completely. It has helped. 

8. Comedy to improve the mood if a little low.

9. Living life in a golden center/middle of healthy responsible moderation.

10. Gratitude for the good whatever it may be. 

God bless everyone. much love and peace. (love yourselves), good friends (which are "hard to come by" go a long way and it's been a real challenge for me to get over all the betrayals I faced due to stigma, but I'm working on it and the above helps me with that too. Tai Chi is \_amazing\_ again and very helpful for me with joy and balance. Much love everyone! God bless!

title: what was your psychosis like ?
content:
i've had a long period of mania (assuming fed by long time use of SSRI and weed ) last year. it endured until 8th of March until my hospitalisation. 

i was in a "spritiual realm" then it got evolved something like im in some kind of "show", where every single event was some kind of test put opon me ... 

a test to decide ... well , it was changing a lot ... for a while i was to be elected as mayor ... and i was watching news and reading newspaper , as if they're talking about me and my campaign.. 

and my campaign ... well... it was how "well i acted" during my stay in solitude at our summer house ( in february ) towards certain events i encountered .

I was talking to people like they're aware of this situation, like they all were part of this. and i was filtering their responses such as .

i was stopping vehicles and asking them questions. 

sometimes these encounters resulted in aggresive situations. 

the last one got me into a fight with street cleaners which resulted in my hospitalisation. 

i was sharing 200+ stories each day on instagram. yes, 200 + ... insta wasn't even letting sharing more than 200, turns out.. it was deleting first ones to open space for last ones. i realised it after some days when somebody warned me ...

yet... this isn'T even the half of what i've done ...

i want to write it all. i want to share it all. but i want to share it with people who would understand. that's why i've started to write this, right now , during my work hour.

but now, i'm bored... and it's getting more boring each day. im procrastinating, surfing on reddit, chatting with GPT, reading e-books , anything but doing my job.

title: I almost admitted myself yesterday
content:
Living is so hard. After my first severe manic episode when I was barely 14, I have never been okay. When I am “okay”, it turns out I was just manic. The lows after mania are awful. It feels like I’m having withdrawals from my own high. My depression is becoming increasingly worse, even though I thought I had found my “sweet spot” a while ago. 
I had to take a medical leave fall semester 2024 and it still kills me inside. Everyone knows me as this perfect, put together person, but I’m genuinely broken and hurting inside. 

I became an RBT January of 2024. I love this job.  For the first time in 7 years, I finally see a future for myself (becoming a BCBA). However, my brain tells me to kill myself every day and night. Every small inconvenience convinces me that nothing is worth it. I think the worst part about my mania right now is that I’m spending so much money and I’m also feeling severe SI. 

The impulsivity is scaring me.  My boyfriend and I had a serious talk about our relationship yesterday, and even though everything ended up fine, it was my last straw. I drove myself to the nearest inpatient unit. I’ve been there twice before so it felt like the safest and closest place I could go to. I called my parents and they drove to me immediately. The only thing that convinced me to go home is my cat. I love her with every fiber of my being. It literally calmed me down so fast it was like a whiplash of emotions. Honestly, my mood swings are terrifying. I could be screaming and banging my head against the wall (which is a new thing for me) and then laugh and be fine a minute later. 

I’m in so much pain but nothing is triggering it in my life. I feel so alone because my medications regulate me to a certain point, so I don’t have the normal bipolar (or at least the severity of it) symptoms. Sometimes I want to get off my meds just to feel what everyone else feels. So that I’m not alone. But I know that would lead to disastrous consequences.

title: Lucid dreaming
content:
So I had a manic episode last February while starting a new job and attending out-of-town training. It was one of the most intense episodes I’ve had and forced me to tell my family about my condition, which I now see as a positive outcome. Before that, only my cousin and one close friend knew.

Here’s the lucid dreaming part: I’ve been able to lucid dream since I was a teenager. It’s not constant, but when I focus on it, I can do it. I’ve heard there might be a connection between lucid dreaming and bipolar disorder, which makes sense since both started around the same time.

Recently, I’ve started to understand why last February’s episode was so intense. My usual process begins with hypomania, where I’m somewhat aware of what’s happening. Once I transition to mania, I lose awareness of my symptoms. This time, my coworkers pointed out traits they assumed were my personality but were actually symptoms of mania. For the first time, I realized I was in the middle of an episode while it was happening—and it terrified me.

It felt like lucid dreaming in real life. In my dreams, I can influence things but not fully control them, and sometimes I lose all control. During the episode, I could see myself acting impulsively, like lying for no reason, and felt like I was in third-person, observing my actions. I was hyper-aware of my symptoms but powerless to stop them. Seeing myself this way for the first time was terrifying, especially realizing the potential destruction I could cause and knowing the lack of control I had over it. 

Ultimately, this awareness pushed me to tell my family and seek help again. 

I don’t know what I am trying to get out of posting this I just didn’t know what to do with this information and don’t really have anyone with possible familiarity to talk about it to.

title: 3 years ago today…

My life before my diagnosis was so tumultuous and exhausting. Being medicated is hard, and sometimes I wish I still had the excitement and energy. I’ve only had one episode since then and it was fun… but so scary. I’m glad I avoided hospital and it cemented to me that treatment is really what I need. 

Not sure why I’m posting this but I am feeling very reflective and wanted to share.

title: uncertain abt bp1
content:
hello everyone, 

I was recently diagnosed with BP 1 and as many question the diagnosis, I do too. For some background I am diagnosed with PTSD & Bipolar 1. I have family members that have bipolar and it’s clear when they are in an episode, but for me, most friends only notice a MAJOR difference when im depressed. It feels like the diagnosis doesn’t make sense & I am planning to communicate with my psych because it’s odd. 

I understand that bp symptoms get triggered especially with stress, and where I live we just had a major stressor due to an ongoing natural disaster and it required me to have to stay with some friends for the time being to be safe. I wasn’t sleeping much for days bcuz friends let me share the room and wouldn’t let me rest longer than 4-6 hours which made me start hallucinating & extremely irritable due to the lack of sleep, so I decided to return home (our warnings were removed for the area) so I finally managed to sleep 12+ hours. Frankly, I was more so worried about even returning home and I had booked a hotel just in case but it turns out that all was okay. I’m confused because something like that would’ve made someone manic/depressive in my opinion? 

For the record, I may be overshooting here and expecting that im supposed to have an episode anytime im stressed out. Frankly ive been super stressed and emotional most of the time, it seems more PTSD related that everything is sort of blunted for me. I’m dealing with more physical symptoms if anything from the stress and it got to the point I was in complete denial that any disaster was happening and started to think maybe it was all fake and the news was just making it seem like it was still ongoing (the skys are clear so I was like ??). I’m not sure what to think, some things do match up to BP but I don’t feel like everything does. If anyone else can relate to any of this and is diagnosed/misdiagnosed can I hear your thoughts on this??

title: How do you apologize and explain a depressive episode?

It felt like a switch went off and he was the worst person alive and I left angry and convinced that he is cheating on me until he can find someone better. I know if I told him this, despite the fact I’ve said I ended relationships during depressive episodes and rationalize vilifying others, he would be shocked and hurt to hear this even if he’s supportive. 

I don’t want to ruin things again, I want to not believe it and that it will just end but I also can’t shake the thoughts and it will eventually get worse. Eventually I will find “evidence” to support isolating and ending everything with anyone because they’re all ruining my life and I don’t need them.

title: Quit yet another job
content:
I quit my job, my last day is later this week.

I don't know who to turn to; I've got no one but my fiancee.  Even then, I feel she's tired of this even though she tells me otherwise.  This is why I'm writing this post; maybe I'll find some inspiration.

I'm to get married this June and I just costed us income again.  I'm so scared.  

I feel it's my depression that makes it difficult for me to keep a job.  At my best, I had a job for a decade until the anxiety and depressive episodes got to me.  I haven't been able to find another steady job since.

My weakness is that I'm below avergae intelligence.  I mess things up, I freeze when tasked with something I don't know how to do.  I get flustered easily. 

I plan on reaching out to a vocational rehab place where I can disclose my bipolar depression.  

I've spent 20 years in IT support, far longer than I should have.  I haven't kept up to date with my skillsets and I have trouble learning new things.  I don't know what else I can do but I plan on getting a job outside of IT for I can't handle the stress of people taking computer issues out on me. 

I wish there was someone on the internet that could help me find a job.  Someone I could talk to and reasonably say "This is what I'm capable of, and this is what I'm not."

I wish I had my peace of mind back.  My personal happiness is tied to having a steady job.  

Could use some advice or helpful input if it's out there.  If not then thank you all the same for reading this post.

title: Have you explained/apologized to people you hurt during your manic episode?
content:
Over the summer, I was misdiagnosed with GAD/ADHD/Depression. I was on the wrong medication for three months and that made me absurdly manic. I definitely made a lot of people uncomfortable, hurt so many others, and pretty much abused everyone I came in contact with. At this point, apologizing/reaching out to people would just re-open old wounds for them. I wish I could apologize or explain the whole situation, but doing so would be so complicated.

The worst situations to be in are the ones where you feel a lot of remorse, shame, and embarrassment. You want to apologize or explain what happened, but doing so would just make things a lot worse.

To those of you that have reached out to people affected by your manic episodes, how did that turn out?

title: Ahhhhh yes, My people!!
content: The bipolar urge to drop everything and create a new life somewhere the fuck else was massive this morning. Like my mania and my depression shook hands and decided he ain’t getting anything done today!! But I unfortunately came out at the top of the mountain! There can only be one driver in this meat suit and he ain’t got time for that!! I found you guys this morning and well fuck I’m glad I did. It’s finally nice to find people that are similar(in the suffering). 💀🥹🥳

title: Random anger with my relationship that I am being overcome with
content:
There’s so much that has occurred in my relationship that got us to rhis point, we have been together for over 5 years now. Pre-COVID even. 

My boyfriend and I live together and we have a very happy life together. But lately I have been angry at him and it makes it hard for feel the usual fondess I do for him. 

I started being angry one day about 3 weeks ago when I saw that he liked the picture of this girl we both follow on instagram, and it was nothing bad or anything but I got irrationally angry feeling like he never bothers to like my own pictures (not entirely true but what I felt ) and so I unfollowed him and removed him from my account , feeling that I’ll at least feel like if he can’t even see what I post, he can’t ignore it by choice. But then I began to feel angry again about these photos he has of him and his ex on his page. 

The shitty on my end thing is that this woman passed away suddenly at only 32. The photos are sweet many of them together and a close up of her eyes, and the caption is heart felt as fuck. In the 5 years we’ve been together he has never posted me and I feel like I’m overshadowed by a very important ghost. At least online. 

I’ve brought it up, and many times the conversation gets very emotional. He has said many times before that he wanted to post us and eventually would but this was already a while ago. This time when he mentioned it I said “no I don’t believe you and even if you did at this point is not even because you want to but because I told you.” 

He says that online doesn’t matter but real life does and we are doing so good , and he is right, I really really want to shake this bitter feeling I feel about our relationship with instagram as a couple. 

The fact that I’ve had to battle with with on and off for 5 years almost is exhausting to me. I hope that shouting it into this void can maybe help me feel heard or something. I know it isn’t quite bipolar related but I and someone who has battled with bipolar and I think maybe the level of rumination I’m having can be a part of it. 

Anyways if you’re feeling that I am immature and need a talking to, please take it a little easy on me. I know you’re right but I am very sensitive .

title: Is this Discipline?
content:
Just a question for y'all.

I have been thinking about self discipline a lot lately and realised that self discipline as somebody who doesn't have medication right now looks a bit weird.

I just wanted to know if other people experience this or if there's a name for it?But essentially I'm talking about the process of accepting feeling really terrible for the sake of doing things I want to do.

When I'm giving myself a break from trying to achieve anything, all my effort goes into neutralising the effects of the disorder. For example I will try respond to dysregulated sleep by enforcing rest regardless of if I can fall asleep or not (lay in a dark room for about 4 hours) or using distraction to not be in the middle of really intense difficult emotions.

When I'm being "disciplined" I essentially say to myself ignore all mental symptoms and instead focus all my effort into doing the thing I want to do. This in turn makes me feel miserable and feel the brunt of my symptoms more but ultimately I feel better because I've been able to practice some autonomy instead of having to handle this disorder I got from chance. For example I will just have terrible sleep and make no attempt to calm myself down when experiencing a fit of crying and continue doing what i'm doing.

Am I even describing discipline? I don't know I just be wondering where my time goes and it's usually going towards trying to make myself feel better so for the sake of self discipline I just don't let myself do anything to feel better. I have so much more time to do things in a day it just sucks more. Anyone else experience this?

Sorry if none of this makes sense y'all my mind is a bit foggy.
